Term.name: systems biology representation

def.defstr: Representation of an entity used in a systems biology knowledge reconstruction, such as a model, pathway, network.

Term.comment: modified as part of ontology 'refactoring' process [SF bug #3172586]

def.defstr: mathematical description that relates quantities of reactants to the reaction velocity.

Term.name: quantitative systems description parameter

def.defstr: A numerical value that defines certain characteristics of systems or system functions. It may be part of a calculation, but its value is not determined by the form of the equation itself, and may be arbitrarily assigned.

Term.comment: Modified as part of ontology 'refactoring' process [SF bug #3172586].

Term.name: participant role

def.defstr: The function of a physical or conceptual entity, that is its role, in the execution of an event or process.

Term.comment: Modified (name) on November 6 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere Name changed from participant functional type to functional parameter on March 17 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere. modified to include conceptual entity [SF req #3509733].

def.defstr: Set of assumptions that underlay a mathematical description.
The description of a system in mathematical terms.
A numerical value that represents the amount of some entity, process or mathematical function of the system.
The 'kind' of entity involved in some process, action or reaction in the system. This may be enzyme, simple chemical, etc..
Basic assumptions that underlie a mathematical model.
Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of a chemical reaction.

Substance consumed by a chemical reaction. Reactants react with each other to form the products of a chemical reaction. In a chemical equation the Reactants are the elements or compounds on the left hand side of the reaction equation. A reactant can be consumed and produced by the same reaction, its global quantity remaining unchanged.

Substance that is produced in a reaction. In a chemical equation the Products are the elements or compounds on the right hand side of the reaction equation. A product can be produced and consumed by the same reaction, its global quantity remaining unchanged.

The Law of Mass Action, first expressed by Waage and Guldberg in 1864 (Waage, P.; Guldberg, C. M. Forhandlinger: Videnskabs-Selskabet i Christiana 1864, 35) states that the speed of a chemical reaction is proportional to the quantity of the reacting substances. More formally, the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of reactant activities. In the case of a reaction occurring in a gas phase, the activities are equal to the partial pressures. In the case of a well-stirred aqueous medium, the activities are equal to the concentrations. In the case of discrete kinetic description, the quantity are expressed in number of molecules and the relevant volume are implicitely embedded in the kinetic constant.
Substance that accelerates the velocity of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed or transformed. This effect is achieved by lowering the free energy of the transition state.
A protein that catalyzes a chemical reaction. The word comes from en ("at" or "in") and simo ("leaven" or "yeast").
Molecule which is acted upon by an enzyme. The substrate binds with the enzyme's active site, and the enzyme catalyzes a chemical reaction involving the substrate.
Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of a chemical reaction involving only one reactant.
Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of a chemical reaction involving two reactants.
Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of a chemical reaction involving three reactants.

Term.name: modifier

def.defstr: Substance that changes the velocity of a process without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction.

Term.comment: Refined definition as part of the term requests by Myers [SF req #3503716].

def.defstr: Substance that decreases the probability of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction.

Substance that increases the probability of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction. This effect is achieved by increasing the difference of free energy between the reactant(s) and the product(s)

Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction involving only one reactant. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactant.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction involving two reactants. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction involving three reactants. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.

Term.name: catalytic rate constant

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of an enzymatic reaction.

Term.comment: "irreversible" removed on March 11 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: new term name

def.defstr: none

Term.comment: created in error

def.defstr: Substrate concentration at which the velocity of reaction is half its maximum. Michaelis constant is an experimental parameter. According to the underlying molecular mechanism it can be interpreted differently in terms of microscopic constants.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible non-modulated non-interacting unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react only with one substance, their substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

First general rate equation for reactions involving enzymes, it was presented in "Victor Henri. Lois Générales de l'Action des Diastases. Paris, Hermann, 1903.". The reaction is assumed to be made of a reversible of the binding of the substrate to the enzyme, followed by the breakdown of the complex generating the product. Ten years after Henri, Michaelis and Menten presented a variant of his equation, based on the hypothesis that the dissociation rate of the substrate was much larger than the rate of the product generation. Leonor Michaelis, Maud Menten (1913). Die Kinetik der Invertinwirkung, Biochem. Z. 49:333-369.

Rate-law presented in "Donald D. Van Slyke and Glenn E. Cullen. The mode of action of urease and of enzymes in general. J. Biol. Chem., Oct 1914; 19: 141-180". It assumes that the enzymatic reaction occurs as two irreversible steps.E+S -> ES -> E+P. Although of the same form than the Henri-Michaelis-Menten equation, it is semantically different since K now represents the ratio between the production rate and the association rate of the enzyme and the substrate.

Term.name: Briggs-Haldane rate law

def.defstr: The Briggs-Haldane rate law is a general rate equation that does not require the restriction of equilibrium of Henri-Michaelis-Menten or irreversible reactions of Van Slyke, but instead make the hypothesis that the complex enzyme-substrate is in quasi-steady-state. Although of the same form than the Henri-Michaelis-Menten equation, it is semantically different since Km now represents a pseudo-equilibrium constant, and is equal to the ratio between the rate of consumption of the complex (sum of dissociation of substrate and generation of product) and the association rate of the enzyme and the substrate.

Term.comment: Rate-law presented by G.E. Briggs and J.B.S. Haldane (1925): "A note on the kinetics of enzyme action, Biochem. J., 19: 338-339".

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction involving only one product. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the product.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction involving only one product. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the product.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction involving three products. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the products.

The reaction scheme does include a reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. The rate of the forward process is proportional to the product of two reactant quantities. The rate of the reverse process is constant. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.name: thermodynamic temperature

def.defstr: Temperature is the physical property of a system which underlies the common notions of "hot" and "cold"; the material with the higher temperature is said to be hotter. Temperature is a quantity related to the average kinetic energy of the particles in a substance. The 10th Conference Generale des Poids et Mesures decided to define the thermodynamic temperature scale by choosing the triple point of water as the fundamental fixed point, and assigning to it the temperature 273,16 degrees Kelvin, exactly (0.01 degree Celsius).

Term.comment: Comptes rendus de la 10e CGPM (1954), 1956, 79

Term.name: temperature difference

def.defstr: Quantity resulting from the difference between two thermodynamic temperatures. A difference or interval of temperature may be expressed in Kelvins or in degrees Celsius.

Term.comment: Comptes rendus de la 13th CGPM, 1967-1968, Resolution 3

def.defstr: Number of molecules which are acted upon by an enzyme.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible non-modulated non-interacting reactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react with one or several substances, their substrates, that bind independently. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible non-modulated non-interacting bireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react with two substances, their substrates, that bind independently. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: superfluous 'n' removed [SF bug #3536623].

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible non-modulated non-interacting trireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react with three substances, their substrates, that bind independently. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: superfluous 'n' removed [SF bug #3536623].

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a discrete framework.
Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.
Number of different substances consumed by a chemical reaction.

Term.name: order of a reaction with respect to a reactant

def.defstr: The order of a reaction with respect to a certain reactant is defined as the power to which its concentration term in the rate equation is raised.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of a chemical reaction where reactants have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction where reactants have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.

Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction where products have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the products.
Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction independant of the reactant quantities. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity.

Term.name: mass action rate law for irreversible reactions, continuous scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from the reactants and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of reactant activities. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.name: second order irreversible mass action kinetics, continuous scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from the reactants and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of reactant activities. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. The change of a product quantity is proportional to two reactant quantity. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.name: third order irreversible mass action kinetics, continuous scheme

It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.name: mass action rate law for irreversible reactions, discrete scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from the reactants and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of reactant activities. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a discrete framework.

Term.name: biochemical or transport reaction

def.defstr: An event involving one or more physical entities that modifies the structure, location or free energy of at least one of the participants.

Term.comment: Modified on 14 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere following the suggestion of Kirill Degtyarenko

Term.name: control

def.defstr: Modification of the execution of an event or a process.

Term.comment: November 10 2006: change "of a reaction" to "of an event"

Term.name: inhibition

def.defstr: Negative modulation of the execution of a process.

Term.comment: Changed "reaction" to "process". NLN

Term.name: stimulation

def.defstr: Positive modulation of the execution of a process.

Term.comment: changed "reaction" to "process"

Term.name: necessary stimulation

def.defstr: Control that is necessary to the execution of a process.

Term.comment: Changed "reaction" to "process". NLN

Term.name: catalysis

def.defstr: Modification of the velocity of a reaction by lowering the energy of the transition state.

Term.comment: November 10 2006; Nicolas Le Novere: becomes a child of "SBO:0000170 ! stimulation"

def.defstr: All the preceding events or participating entities are necessary to perform the control.
Any of the preceding events or participating entities are necessary to perform the control.
Only one of the preceding events or participating entities can perform the control at one time.

Term.name: biochemical reaction

def.defstr: An event involving one or more chemical entities that modifies the electrochemical structure of at least one of the participants.

Term.comment: Modified on 14 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere following the suggestion of Kirill Degtyarenko

Term.name: non-covalent binding

def.defstr: Interaction between several biochemical entities that results in the formation of a non-covalent complex

Term.comment: "non-covalent" added on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere. added synonym [SF req #3503970]

def.defstr: Rupture of a covalent bond resulting in the conversion of one physical entity into several physical entities.
Complete disappearance of a physical entity.
Transformation of a non-covalent complex that results in the formation of several independent biochemical entities

Term.name: conformational transition

def.defstr: Biochemical reaction that does not result in the modification of covalent bonds of reactants, but rather modifies the conformation of some reactants, that is the relative position of their atoms in space.

Term.comment: Renamed on September 20 2006, following the suggestion of Hiroaki Kitano.

def.defstr: Biochemical reaction that results in the modification of some covalent bonds.

Term.name: transcription

def.defstr: Process through which a DNA sequence is copied to produce a complementary RNA.

Term.comment: See GO:0006350 Definition modified on 09 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: translation

def.defstr: Process in which a polypeptide chain is produced from a messenger RNA.

Term.comment: see GO:0043037 Definition modified on 09 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

def.defstr: Movement of a physical entity without modification of the structure of the entity.

Term.name: maximal velocity

def.defstr: Limiting maximal velocity of an enzymatic reaction, reached when the substrate is in large excess and all the enzyme is complexed.

Term.comment: The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

def.defstr: Version of Henri-Michaelis-Menten equation where kp*[E]t is replaced by the maximal velocity, Vmax, reached when all the enzyme is active.

Term.name: number of biochemical items

def.defstr: A number of objects of the same type, identical or different, involved in a biochemical event.

Term.comment: Added "biochemical" in the name on November 10 2006; Nicolas Le Novere.

def.defstr: Number of regions on a reactant to which specific other reactants, in this context collectively called ligands, form a chemical bond.

Term.name: Hill coefficient

def.defstr: Empirical parameter created by Archibald Vivian Hill to describe the cooperative binding of oxygen on hemoglobine (Hill (1910). The possible effects of the aggregation of the molecules of haemoglobin on its dissociation curves. J Physiol 40: iv-vii).

Term.comment: Determined from a "Hill plot", it is sometimes assumed to be the number of binding or catalytic sites in a polymer, but it is incorrect. In some mechanistic model, the Hill coefficient gives a lower limit for the number of sites.

def.defstr: Empirical constant created by Archibald Vivian Hill to describe the cooperative binding of oxygen on hemoglobine (Hill (1910). The possible effects of the aggregation of the molecules of haemoglobin on its dissociation curves. J Physiol 40: iv-vii). Different from a microscopic dissociation constant, it has the dimension of concentration to the power of the Hill coefficient.

Term.name: Hill-type rate law, generalised form

def.defstr: Empirical equation created by Archibald Vivian Hill to describe the cooperative binding of oxygen on hemoglobine (Hill (1910). The possible effects of the aggregation of the molecules of haemoglobin on its dissociation curves. J Physiol 40: iv-vii).

Term.comment: The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

def.defstr: Constant with the dimension of a powered concentration. It is determined at half-saturation, half-activity etc.
Dissociation constant equivalent to an intrinsic microscopic dissociation constant, but obtained from an averaging process, for instance by extracting the root of a Hill constant.

Term.name: Hill-type rate law, microscopic form

def.defstr: Hill equation rewritten by creating a pseudo-microscopic constant, equal to the Hill constant powered to the opposite of the Hill coefficient.

Term.comment: The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

def.defstr: The amount of an entity per unit of volume.
Concentration of an object divided by the value of another parameter having the dimension of a concentration.

Term.name: Hill-type rate law, reduced form

def.defstr: Hill equation rewritten by replacing the concentration of reactant with its reduced form, that is the concentration divide by a pseudo-microscopic constant, equal to the Hill constant powered to the opposite of the Hill coefficient.

Term.comment: The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

Term.name: normalised enzymatic rate law for unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react only with one substance, their substrate. The total enzyme concentration is considered to be equal to 1, therefore the maximal velocity equals the catalytic constant.

Term.name: redox reaction

def.defstr: Chemical process in which atoms have their oxidation number (oxidation state) changed.

Term.comment: Added on 09 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere following the suggestion of Emek Demir.

def.defstr: Chemical process during which a molecular entity loses electrons.

Term.name: reduction

def.defstr: Chemical process in which a molecular entity gain electrons.

Term.comment: Added on 09 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: duplication

def.defstr: Reaction in which a reactant gives birth to two products identical to itself.

Term.comment: Added on 09 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere to allow the creation of "replication".

Term.name: DNA replication

def.defstr: Process in which a DNA duplex is transformed into two identical DNA duplexes.

Term.comment: See GO:0006260 Added on 09 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Emek Demir. Modified 04 July 2008 by Nick Juty - changed from replication to dna replication

Term.name: composite biochemical process

def.defstr: Process that involves the participation of chemical or biological entities and is composed of several elementary steps or reactions.

Term.comment: 30/9/08 - modified term name from 'biochemical process' to 'composite biochemical process' - NJ "event"->"process" in definition on November 18 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: competitive inhibitor

def.defstr: Substance that decreases the probability of a chemical reaction, without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction, by stericaly hindering the interaction between reactants.

Term.comment: Added on 14 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

def.defstr: Substance that decreases the probability of a chemical reaction, without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction, and without sterically hindering the interaction between reactants.

Term.name: acid-base reaction

def.defstr: Chemical reaction where a proton is given by a compound, the acid, to another one, the base (Brønsted-Lowry definition). An alternative, more general, definition is a reaction where a compound, the base, gives a pair of electrons to another, the acid (Lewis definition).

Term.comment: Created on 24 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: ionisation

def.defstr: Ionization is the physical process of converting an atom or molecule into an ion by changing the difference between the number of protons and electrons.

Term.comment: Created on 24 August 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: addition of a chemical group

def.defstr: Covalent reaction that results in the addition of a chemical group on a molecule.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere based on Patika ontology.

Term.name: removal of a chemical group

def.defstr: Covalent reaction that results in the removal of a chemical group from a molecule.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere based on Patika ontology.

Term.name: protonation

def.defstr: Addition of a proton (H+) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: deprotonation

def.defstr: Removal of a proton (hydrogen ion H+) from a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: methylation

def.defstr: Addition of a methyl group (-CH3) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: acetylation

def.defstr: Addition of an acetyl group (-COCH3) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: phosphorylation

def.defstr: Addition of a phosphate group (-H2PO4) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: glycosylation

def.defstr: Addition of a saccharide group to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: palmitoylation

def.defstr: Addition of a palmitoyl group (CH3-[CH2]14-CO-) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: myristoylation

def.defstr: Addition of a myristoyl (CH3-[CH2]12-CO-) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: sulfation

def.defstr: Addition of a sulfate group (SO4--) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: prenylation

def.defstr: Addition of a prenyl group (generic sense) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: farnesylation

def.defstr: Addition of a farnesyl group (CH2-CH=C(CH3)-CH2-CH2-CH=C(CH3)-CH2-CH2-CH=C(CH3)2) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: geranylgeranylation

def.defstr: Addition of a geranylgeranyl group (CH2-CH=C(CH3)-CH2-CH2-CH=C(CH3)-CH2-CH2-CH=C(CH3)-CH2-CH2-CH=C(CH3)2) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: ubiquitination

def.defstr: Covalent linkage to the protein ubiquitin.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: delay

def.defstr: Time during which some action is awaited.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

def.defstr: A quantitative measure of an amount or property of an entity expressed in terms of another dimension, such as unit length, area or volume.
The mass of an entity expressed with reference to another dimension, such as unit length, area or volume.
Mass of an entity per unit volume.

Term.name: area density of an entity

def.defstr: The mass of an entity per unit of surface area.

Term.comment: Added on September 13 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

def.defstr: Mass of an entity per unit length.

Term.name: occurring entity representation

def.defstr: Representation of an entity that manifests, unfolds or develops through time, such as a discrete event, or a mutual or reciprocal action or influence that happens between participating physical entities, and/or other occurring entities.

Term.comment: modified as part of ontology 'refactoring' process [SF bug #3172586] Name changed to "interaction" on November 18 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere. Definition changed to mention interaction with other interactions, in order to cover "process" and "relationship".

def.defstr: A phenomenon that takes place and which may be observable, or may be determined to have occurred as the result of an action or process.

Term.name: hydroxylation

def.defstr: Addition of an hydroxyl group (-OH) to a chemical entity.

Term.comment: Added on September 20 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: logical framework

def.defstr: Modelling approach, pioneered by Rene Thomas and Stuart Kaufman, where the evolution of a system is described by the transitions between discrete activity states of "genes" that control each other.

Term.comment: Created on October 17 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

def.defstr: Entity that affects or is affected by an event.

Term.name: physical entity representation

def.defstr: Representation of an entity that may participate in an interaction, a process or relationship of significance.

Term.comment: modified as part of ontology 'refactoring' process [SF bug #3172586] 18 November 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere: Name reduced to entity, and definition modified.

Term.name: logical combination

def.defstr: Combining the influence of several entities or events in a unique influence.

Term.comment: Created by Nicolas Le Novere on November 10 2006. "logical" added in the name by Nicolas Le Novere on November 17 2008.

Term.name: not

def.defstr: The preceding event or participating entity cannot participate to the control.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: allosteric control

def.defstr: Regulation of the influence of a reaction participant by binding an effector to a binding site of the participant different of the site of the participant conveying the influence.

Term.comment: Create on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: material entity

def.defstr: A real thing that is defined by its physico-chemical structure.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: functional entity

def.defstr: A real thing, defined by its properties or the actions it performs, rather than it physico-chemical structure.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere. Name changed from "conceptual" to "functional" on November 18 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere.

def.defstr: A component that allows another component to pass through itself, possibly connecting different compartments.

Term.name: gene

def.defstr:
A locatable region of genomic sequence, corresponding to a unit of inheritance, which is associated with regulatory regions, transcribed regions and/or other functional sequence regions.
Sequence Ontology SO:0000704

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: receptor

def.defstr:
Participating entity that binds to a specific physical entity and initiates the response to that physical entity.The original concept of the receptor was introduced independently at the end of the 19th century by John Newport Langley (1852-1925) and Paul Ehrlich (1854-1915).
Langley JN.On the reaction of cells and of nerve-endings to certain poisons, chiefly as regards the reaction of striated muscle to nicotine and to curari. J Physiol. 1905 Dec 30;33(4-5):374-413.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: macromolecule

def.defstr:
Molecular entity mainly built-up by the repetition of pseudo-identical units.
CHEBI:33839

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: information macromolecule

def.defstr: Macromolecule whose sequence is encoded in the genome of living organisms.

Term.comment: Cf. CHEBI:33695

Term.name: simple chemical

def.defstr: Simple, non-repetitive chemical entity.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

def.defstr: Macromolecule whose sequence is not directly encoded in the genome.

Term.name: polysaccharide

def.defstr:
Macromolecule consisting of a large number of monosaccharide residues linked by glycosidic bonds.
CHEBI:18154

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: ribonucleic acid

def.defstr:
Macromolecule formed by a repetition of ribonucleosides linked by phosphodiester bonds.
CHEBI:33697

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: deoxyribonucleic acid

def.defstr:
Polymer composed of nucleotides containing deoxyribose and linked by phosphodiester bonds.
CHEBI:16991

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: polypeptide chain

def.defstr:
Naturally occurring macromolecule formed by the repetition of amino-acid residues linked by peptidic bonds. A polypeptide chain is synthesized by the ribosome.
CHEBI:16541

Term.comment: Name changed on January 10 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere, to disambiguate from non-ribosomal peptides. Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: non-covalent complex

def.defstr: Entity composed of several independant components that are not linked by covalent bonds.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: electrical resistance

def.defstr: Measure of the degree to which an object opposes the passage of an electric current. The SI unit of electrical resistance is the ohm.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: physical characteristic

def.defstr: Parameter characterising a physical system or the environment, and independent of life's influence.

Term.comment: Name modified from physical parameter to physical characteristic on March 17 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere. Terms 'biochemical parameter' (SBO:0000256) and 'physical characteristic' (SBO:0000255) obsoleted as described by SourceForge Tracker #3102840. Please use parent term 'quantitative parameter', SBO:0000002, or a more suitable term.

Term.name: biochemical parameter

def.defstr: Parameter that depends on the biochemical properties of a system.

Term.comment: Terms 'biochemical parameter' (SBO:0000256) and 'physical characteristic' (SBO:0000255) obsoleted as described by SourceForge Tracker #3102840. Please use parent term 'quantitative parameter', SBO:0000002, or a more suitable term.

def.defstr: Measure of how easily electricity flows along a certain path through an electrical element. The SI derived unit of conductance is the Siemens.

Term.name: capacitance

def.defstr: Measure of the amount of electric charge stored (or separated) for a given electric potential. The unit of capacitance id the Farad.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: voltage

def.defstr: Difference of electrical potential between two points of an electrical network, expressed in volts.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by one inhibitor

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor that binds once to the free enzyme and prevents the binding of the substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

synonym.synonym_text: simple intersecting linear competitive inhibition of unireactant enzymes

Term.name: inhibitory constant

def.defstr: Dissociation constant of a compound from a target of which it inhibits the function.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple uncompetitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor that binds only to the complex enzyme-substrate and totally prevent the catalysis. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: relative equilibrium constant

def.defstr: Ratio of an equilibrium constant in a given condition by the same equilibrium constant is not fullfilled.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: relative inhibition constant

def.defstr: Ratio of the dissociation constant of an inhibitor from the complex enzyme-substrate on the dissociation constant of an inhibitor from the free enzyme.

Term.comment: Created on November 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple mixed-type inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor that can bind to the complex enzyme-substrate and the free enzyme, possibly with different equilibrium constant, and totally prevent the catalysis. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

synonym.synonym_text: simple intersecting linear mixed-type competitive inhibition

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple irreversible non-competitive inhibition of unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor that can bind to the complex enzyme-substrate and the free enzyme with the same equilibrium constant, and totally prevent the catalysis.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by one inhibitor

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor that can bind one or several times to the free enzyme, and prevent the binding of the substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

synonym.synonym_text: multiple competitive inhibition by one inhibitor of unireactant enzymes

Term.comment: n indicates the number of binding sites for the inhibitor I.

def.defstr: Enzyme kinetics is the study of the rates of chemical reactions that are catalysed by enzymes, how this rate is controlled, and how drugs and poisons can inhibit its activity.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that catalyse the transformation of only one substrate.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by exclusive inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by inhibitors that bind to the free enzyme on the same binding site than the substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by two exclusive inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by two inhibitors that bind to the free enzyme on the same binding site than the substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: number of inhibitors

def.defstr: Number of entities that inhibit a reaction.

Term.comment: Created on November 11 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by non-exclusive non-cooperative inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by inhibitors that bind independently to the free enzyme and preclude the binding of the substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: n indicates the number of inhibitors, and mi the number of binding sites for the inhibitor Ii.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by two non-exclusive, non-cooperative inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by two inhibitors that can bind independently once to the free enzyme and preclude the binding of the substrate. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for mixed-type inhibition of irreversible enzymes by mutually exclusive inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by inhibitors that can bind to the complex enzyme-substrate and the free enzyme, possibly with different equilibrium constants, and totally prevent the catalysis. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for mixed-type inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by two inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of unireactant enzymes by two inhibitors that can bind to the complex enzyme-substrate and the free enzyme, possibly with different equilibrium constant, and totally prevent the catalysis. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for non-competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by two exclusively binding inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of unireactant enzymes by two inhibitors that can bind to the complex enzyme-substrate and the free enzyme with the same equilibrium constant and totally prevent the catalysis.

Term.name: messenger RNA

def.defstr: A messenger RNA is a ribonucleic acid synthesized during the transcription of a gene, and that carries the information to encode one or several proteins.

Term.comment: Created on November 16 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: pressure

def.defstr: Pressure (symbol: p) is the force per unit area applied on a surface in a direction perpendicular to that surface. The unit of pressure is the Pascal (Pa), that is equal to 1 Newton per square meter.

Term.comment: Created on November 21 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: ligand

def.defstr: In biochemistry, a ligand is an effector, a physical entity that binds to a site on a receptor's surface by intermolecular forces.

Term.comment: Created on November 27 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: equilibrium constant

def.defstr: Quantity characterizing a chemical equilibrium in a chemical reaction, which is a useful tool to determine the concentration of various reactants or products in a system where chemical equilibrium occurs.

Term.comment: Created on November 27 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Martin Golebiewski.

Term.name: dissociation constant

def.defstr: Equilibrium constant that measures the propensity of a larger object to separate (dissociate) reversibly into smaller components, as when a complex falls apart into its component molecules, or when a salt splits up into its component ions. The dissociation constant is usually denoted Kd and is the inverse of the affinity constant.

Term.comment: Created on November 27 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: acid dissociation constant

def.defstr: Equilibrium constant that indicates the extent of dissociation of hydrogen ions from an acid. The equilibrium is that of a proton transfer from an acid, HA, to water, H2O. The term for the concentration of water, [H2O], is omitted from the general equilibrium constant expression. Ka=([H3O+]*[A-])/(HA)

Term.comment: Created on November 27 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere on a suggestion by Martin Golebviewski

Term.name: transporter

def.defstr: Participating entity that facilitates the movement of another physical entity from a defined subset of the physical environment (for instance a cellular compartment) to another.

Term.comment: Created on November 28 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

def.defstr: Material entity whose nature is unknown or irrelevant.

Term.name: multimer

def.defstr: Non-covalent association of identical, or pseudo-identical, entities. By pseudo-identical entities, we mean biochemical elements that differ chemically, although remaining globally identical in structure and/or function. Examples are homologous subunits in an hetero-oligomeric receptor.

Term.comment: Created on December 1 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: EC50

def.defstr: Concentration of an active compound at which 50% of its maximal effect is observed. The EC50 is not a pure characteristic of the compound but depends on the conditions or the measurement.

Term.comment: Created on December 7th 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Martin Golebiewski

Term.name: IC50

def.defstr: Also called half maximal inhibitory concentration, it represents the concentration of an inhibitor substance that is required to suppress 50% of an effect.

Term.comment: Created on December 7 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere on the request of Martin Golebiewski.

Term.name: functional compartment

def.defstr: Logical or physical subset of the event space that contains pools, that is sets of participants considered identical when it comes to the event they are involved into. A compartment can have any number of dimensions, including 0, and be of any size including null.

Term.comment: Created on December 11 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: physical compartment

def.defstr: Specific location of space, that can be bounded or not. A physical compartment can have 1, 2 or 3 dimensions.

Term.comment: Created on December 14 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: empty set

def.defstr: Entity defined by the absence of any actual object. An empty set is often used to represent the source of a creation process or the result of a degradation process.

Term.comment: moved from conceptual to material entity

Term.name: spatial continuous framework

def.defstr: Modelling approach where the quantities of participants are considered continuous, and represented by real values. The associated simulation methods make use of differential equations. The models take into account the distribution of the entities and describe the spatial fluxes.

Term.comment: Created on December 22 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: non-spatial continuous framework

def.defstr: Modelling approach where the quantities of participants are considered continuous, and represented by real values. The associated simulation methods make use of differential equations. The models do not take into account the distribution of the entities and describe only the temporal fluxes.

Term.comment: Created on December 22 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: spatial discrete framework

def.defstr: Modelling approach where the quantities of participants are considered discrete, and represented by integer values. The associated simulation methods can be deterministic or stochastic. The models take into account the distribution of the entities and describe the spatial fluxes.

Term.comment: Created on December 22 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: non-spatial discrete framework

def.defstr: Modelling approach where the quantities of participants are considered discrete, and represented by integer values. The associated simulation methods can be deterministic or stochastic.The models do not take into account the distribution of the entities and describe only the temporal fluxes.

Term.comment: Created on Decemer 22 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: macromolecular complex

def.defstr: Non-covalent complex of one or more macromolecules and zero or more simple chemicals.

Term.comment: Created on January 10 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: protein complex

def.defstr:
Macromolecular complex containing one or more polypeptide chains possibly associated with simple chemicals.
CHEBI:36080

Term.comment: Created on January 10 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Douglas Kell

Term.name: synthetic chemical compound

def.defstr: Chemical entity that is engineered by a human-designed process ex-vivo rather than a produced by a living entity.

Term.comment: Created on January 10 2006 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: metabolite

def.defstr: Substance produced by metabolism or by a metabolic process.

Term.comment: Created on January 10 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Douglas Kell

Term.name: total concentration of enzyme

def.defstr: Total amount of enzyme catalysing a reaction, divided by the volume of reaction.

Term.comment: Created on January 20 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: total catalytic efficiency

def.defstr:
Constant representing the actual efficiency of an enzyme at a given concentration, taking into account its microscopic catalytic activity and the rates of substrate binding and dissociation.
NB. The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

Term.comment: Created on January 20 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere May 15 2008: Added a note of usage of Vmax following comment from Andreas Draeger

Term.name: catalytic efficiency

def.defstr: Constant representing the actual efficiency of an enzyme, taking into account its microscopic catalytic activity and the rates of substrate binding and dissociation.

Term.comment: Created on January 20 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: biochemical potential

def.defstr: Derivative of a biochemical energy per a substance.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: pH

def.defstr: Negative logarithm (base 10) of the activity of hydrogen in a solution. Ina diluted solution, this activity is equal to the concentration of protons (in fact of ions H3O+). The pH is proportional to the chemical potential of hydrogen, by the relation: pH = -µH ÷ 2.3RT. (with µH=-RTln[H+]).

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: pOH

def.defstr: Negative logarithm (base 10) of the activity of hydroxyde in a solution. In a diluted solution, this activity is equal to the concentration of ions HO-.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: pK

def.defstr: negative logarithm (base 10) of a dissociation constant.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere on a suggestion of Martin Golebiewski.

Term.name: pKa

def.defstr: negative logarithm (base 10) of an acid dissociation constant.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: equilibrium or steady-state characteristic

def.defstr: Quantitative parameter that characterises a biochemical equilibrium.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: dissociation characteristic

def.defstr: Quantitative parameter that characterises a dissociation.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: acid dissociation characteristic

def.defstr: Quantitative parameter that characterises an acid-base reaction.

Term.comment: Created on February 3 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: heterogeneous nuclear RNA

def.defstr: Incompletely processed single strand of messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA), synthesized from a DNA template in the nucleus of a cell by transcription and containing copies of the introns and exons of a gene.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: mature messenger RNA

def.defstr: Completely processed single strand of messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA), synthesized from a DNA template in the nucleus of a cell by transcription and containing copies of only the exons of a gene.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: transfer RNA

def.defstr: Small RNA chain (73-93 nucleotides) that transfers a specific amino acid to a growing polypeptide chain at the ribosomal site of protein synthesis during translation. It has a site for amino acid attachment and a three-base region called the anticodon that recognizes the corresponding three-base codon region on mRNA via complementary base pairing. Each type of tRNA molecule can be attached to only one type of amino acid, but because the genetic code is degenerate - that is, it contains multiple codons that specify the same amino acid - multiple types of tRNA molecules bearing different anticodons may carry the same amino acid.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: ribosomal RNA

def.defstr: Type of RNA that is the central component of the ribosome, the protein manufacturing machinery of all living cells.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: ribozyme

def.defstr: RNA molecule that catalyzes a chemical reaction.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: microRNA

def.defstr: Single-stranded RNA molecules thought to regulate the expression of other genes. miRNAs are encoded by genes that are transcribed from DNA but not translated into protein (non-coding RNA).

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: small interfering RNA

def.defstr: siRNA are 20-25 nucleotide-long double-stranded RNA molecules involved in the regulation of the expression of specific genes, antiviral mechanisms, shaping the chromatin structure of a genome etc.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: small nuclear RNA

def.defstr: Small RNA molecules that are found within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. They are involved in a variety of important processes such as RNA splicing (removal of introns from heterogeneous nuclear RNA), regulation of transcription factors or RNA polymerase II and maintaining the telomeres. They are always associated with specific proteins, and the complexes are referred to as small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNP).

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: small nucleolar RNA

def.defstr: Small RNA molecules that guide chemical modifications (methylation or pseudouridylation) of ribosomal RNAs (rRNAs) and other RNA genes. They are frequently encoded in the introns of ribosomal proteins and are synthesized by RNA polymerase II, but can also be transcribed as independent (sometimes polycistronic) transcriptional units. snoRNAs are a component in the small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein (snoRNP), which contains snoRNA and proteins.

Term.comment: Created on March 12 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere with help from Laure Gambardella

Term.name: product catalytic rate constant

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of product creation by a reversible enzymatic reaction.

Term.comment: Created on March 11 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: substrate catalytic rate constant

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the velocity of substrate creation by a reversible enzymatic reaction.

Term.comment: Created on March 11 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: Michaelis constant for substrate

def.defstr: Substrate concentration at which the velocity of product production by the forward activity of a reversible enzyme is half its maximum.

Term.comment: Created on March 11 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: Michaelis constant for product

def.defstr: Product concentration at which the velocity of substrate production by the reverse activity of a reversible enzyme is half its maximum.

Term.comment: Created on March 11 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: forward maximal velocity

def.defstr: Limiting maximal velocity of the forward reaction of a reversible enzyme, reached when the substrate is in large excess and all the enzyme is complexed.

Term.comment: The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

Term.name: reverse maximal velocity

def.defstr: Limiting maximal velocity of the reverse reaction of a reversible enzyme, reached when the product is in large excess and all the enzyme is complexed.

Term.comment: The symbol Vmax and the names maximum rate and maximum velocity are in widespread use although under normal circumstances there is no finite substrate concentration at which v = V and hence no maximum in the mathematical sense (Eur. J. Biochem. 128:281-291).

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for non-modulated unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react only with one substance, their substrate, and are not modulated by other compounds.

Term.name: non-macromolecular ion

def.defstr: Chemical entity having a net electric charge.

Term.comment: Created on March 18 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: non-macromolecular radical

def.defstr: chemical entity possessing an unpaired electron.

Term.comment: Created on March 18 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

Term.name: transcription start site

def.defstr:
First nucleotide of a gene that is copied in the transcribed RNA.
Sequence Ontology SO:0000315

Term.comment: Created on September 28 2007 by Nicolas Le Novere.

def.defstr: Removal of a phosphate group (-H2PO4) from a chemical entity.
Time interval over which a quantified entity is reduced to half its original value.
Time taken by a quantity decreasing according to a mono-exponential decay to be divided by two. Sometimes called t1/2.
Monotonic decrease of a quantity proportionally to its value.

Term.name: non-coding RNA

def.defstr:
RNA molecule that is not translated into a protein.
Sequence Ontology SO:0000655

Term.comment: Created on 03 January 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: gene coding region

def.defstr: Portion of DNA or RNA that is transcribed into another RNA, such as a messenger RNA or a non-coding RNA (for instance a transfert RNA or a ribosomal RNA).

Term.comment: Created on January 03 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: interactor

def.defstr: Entity participating in a physical or functional interaction.

Term.comment: Created on January 31 2008 on the suggestion of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: association constant

def.defstr: Equilibrium constant that measures the propensity of two objects to assemble (associate) reversibly into a larger component. The association constant is usually denoted Ka and is the inverse of the dissociation constant.

Term.comment: Created on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the request of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: dissociation rate constant

def.defstr: Rate with which a complex dissociates into its components.

Term.comment: Created on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the request of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: bimolecular association rate constant

def.defstr: Rate with which two components associate into a complex.

Term.comment: Created on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the request of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: trimolecular association rate constant

def.defstr: Rate with which three components associate into a complex.

Term.comment: created on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: association rate constant

def.defstr: Rate with which components associate into a complex.

Term.comment: Created on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: molecular or genetic interaction

def.defstr: Mutual or reciprocal action or influence between molecular entities.

Term.comment: Created on February 16 2008 byt Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: genetic interaction

def.defstr: A phenomenon whereby an observed phenotype, qualitative or quantative, is not explainable by the simple additive effects of the individual gene pertubations alone. Genetic interaction between perturbed genes is usually expected to generate a 'defective' phenotype. The level of defectiveness is often used to sub-classify this phenomenon.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_interaction SBO:0000499 'genetic interaction' deprecated.

Term.name: molecular interaction

def.defstr: Relationship between molecular entities, based on contacts, direct or indirect.

Term.comment: Created on February 26 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Samuel Kerrien.

Term.name: time

def.defstr: Fundmental quantity of the measuring system used to sequence events, to compare the durations of events and the intervals between them, and to quantify the motions or the transformation of entities. The SI base unit for time is the SI second. The second is the duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium 133 atom.

Term.comment: Created on February 28 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Martin Golebievski

def.defstr: Fundamental quantity of the measuring system used to sequence events, to compare the durations of events and the intervals between them, and to quantify the motions or the transformation of entities. The SI base unit for time is the SI second. The second is the duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium 133 atom.
Amount of time during which an event persists.

Time that it takes for an exponential decay to reach 1/e (about 37%) of the original value. This characterises the frequency response of a first-order, linear time-invariant system. This is also the average lifetime of an element in the decaying set. It is the inverse of the exponential decay constant.

Term.name: inactivation rate constant

def.defstr: Kinetic constant describing the rate of an irreversible enzyme inactivation by decay of the active enzyme into its inactive form.

Term.comment: Created on February 29 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the request of Martin Golebvieski

Term.name: forward reaction velocity

def.defstr: The speed of an enzymatic reaction at a defined concentration of substrate(s) and enzyme.

Term.comment: created by Nick Juty on March 28th 2008 on request of Martin Golebvieski

Term.name: reverse zeroth order rate constant

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction independant of the reactant quantities. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.comment: Created by Nick Juty 28th March 2008

Term.name: reverse reaction velocity

def.defstr: The speed of an enzymatic reaction at a defined concentration of substrate(s) and enzyme.

Term.comment: Created by Nick Juty 28th March 2008

Term.name: informational molecule segment

def.defstr: Fragment of a macromolecule that carries genetic information.

Term.comment: Created by Nicolas Le Novere on April 23 2008 on the suggestion of SBGN forum

Term.name: conservation law

def.defstr: Mathematical expression stating that a quantity is conserved in a system, whatever happens within the boundaries of that system.

Term.comment: Created on April 25 by Nicolas Le Novere, on the demand of SBML forum

Term.name: decay constant

def.defstr: Kinetic constant characterising a mono-exponential decay. It is the inverse of the mean lifetime of the continuant being decayed. Its unit is "per time".

Term.comment: Created on April 29 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: biological effect of a perturbation

def.defstr: Biochemical networks can be affected by external influences. Those influences can be well-defined physical perturbations, such as a light pulse, or a change in temperature but also more complex of not well defined phenomena, for instance a biological process, an experimental setup, or a mutation.

Term.comment: Created on May 07 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere for SBGN needs.

Term.name: phenotype

def.defstr: A biochemical network can generate phenotypes or affects biological processes. Such processes can take place at different levels and are independent of the biochemical network itself.

Term.comment: Potentially obsolete....use with caution

Term.name: mass conservation law

def.defstr: A chemical moiety that exists under different forms but is not created nor destroyed in a biochemical system. In any given system such a conserved moiety is characterized by a finite number of particles that exist in the system and is invariant.

Term.comment: Created on May 9th 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Pedro Mendes and Stefan Hoops.

def.defstr: The enumeration of co-localised, identical biochemical entities of a specific state, which constitute a pool. The form of enumeration may be purely numerical, or may be given in relation to another dimension such as length or volume.
A numerical measure of the quantity, or of some property, of the entities that constitute the entity pool.

Term.name: concentration conservation law

def.defstr: If all forms of a moiety exist in a single compartment and the size of that compartment is fixed then the Mass Conservation is also a Concentration Conservation.

Term.comment: Created on May 9th 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere on the suggestion of Stefan Hoops

Term.name: activation constant

def.defstr: Dissociation constant of a potentiator (activator) from a target (e.g. an enzyme) of which it activates the function.

Term.comment: Created 20th May 2008 by Nick Juty on the request of Martin Golebiewski.

Term.name: multimer cardinality

def.defstr: Number of monomers composing a multimeric entity.

Term.comment: Created on May 23 by Nicolas Le Novere for SBGN need.

Term.name: forward non-integral order rate constant, continuous case

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction where reactants have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants.It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.comment: created 4th June 2008 - Nick Juty

Term.name: forward non-integral order rate constant, discrete case

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the forward velocity of a chemical reaction where reactants have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the reactants. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a discrete framework.

Term.comment: created 4th June 2008 - Nick Juty

Term.name: reverse non-integral order rate constant, discrete case

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction where products have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the products. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a discrete framework.

Term.comment: created 4th June 2008 - Nick Juty

Term.name: reverse non-integral order rate constant, continuous case

def.defstr: Numerical parameter that quantifies the reverse velocity of a chemical reaction where products have non-integral orders. This parameter encompasses all the contributions to the velocity except the quantity of the products. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.comment: created 4th June 2008 - Nick Juty

Term.name: gene regulatory region

def.defstr: Region of a gene that is involved in the modulation of the expression of the gene.

Term.comment: Created for SBGN purposes.

Term.name: Michaelis constant in non-equilibrium situation

def.defstr: Michaelis constant derived or experimentally measured under non-equilibrium conditions.

Term.comment: Created 11th July 2008 by Nick Juty (with Lukas Endler and Nicolas Le Novere)

Term.name: Michaelis constant in quasi-steady state situation

def.defstr: Michaelis constant derived using a steady-state assumption for enzyme-substrate and enzyme-product intermediates. For example see Briggs-Haldane equation (SBO:0000031).

Term.comment: Created 11th July 2008 by Nick Juty (with Lukas Endler and Nicolas Le Novere)

Term.name: Michaelis constant in irreversible situation

def.defstr: Michaelis constant derived assuming enzyme-substrate and enzyme-product intermediates are formed in consecutive irreversible reactions. The constant K is the ratio of the forward rate constants. For example see Van Slyke-Cullen equation (SBO:0000030).

Term.comment: Created 11th July 2008 by Nick Juty (with Lukas Endler and Nicolas Le Novere)

Term.name: Michaelis constant in fast equilibrium situation

def.defstr: Michaelis constant as determined in a reaction where the formation of the enzyme-substrate complex occurs at a much faster rate than subsequent steps, and so are assumed to be in a quasi-equilibrium situation. K is equivalent to an equilibrium constant. For example see Henri-Michaelis-Menten equation (SBO:0000029).

Term.comment: Modified for clarification [SF req #2969519]

Term.name: relationship

def.defstr: connectedness between entities and/or interactions representing their relatedness or influence.

Term.comment: Name and definition changed on November 18 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: process

def.defstr: A sequential series of actions, motions, or occurrences, such as chemical reactions, that affect one or more entities in a phenomenologically characteristic manner.

Term.comment: definition modified 21/10/08 - NJ name and definition modified 18/Nov/2008 - Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: hydrolysis

def.defstr: Decomposition of a compound by reaction with water, where the hydroxyl and H groups are incorporated into different products

Term.comment: Created 30/9/08 - NJ

Term.name: isomerisation

def.defstr: A reaction in which the principal reactant and principal product are isomers of each other

Term.comment: Created 30/9/08 - NJ

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by competing substrates

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by competing substrates (Sa) that bind to the free enzyme on the same binding site. The enzyme does not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: See Cornish-Bowden Fundementals of Enzyme Kinetics (3rd Edition 2004): Ch5.6, pp127.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by two non-exclusive inhibitors

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by two inhibitors that can bind once to the free enzyme and preclude the binding of the substrate. Binding of one inhibitor may affect binding of the other, or not. The enzymes do not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: See Segel I., Enzyme Kinetics, Wiley-Interscience;1993, ISBN 0-471-30309-7, Chapter 8, System B3, pp481.

Term.name: biochemical coefficient

def.defstr: number used as a multiplicative or exponential factor for quantities, expressions or functions

Term.comment: created by Lukas Endler and Nick Juty 17/9/08

Term.name: biochemical proportionality coefficient

def.defstr: A multiplicative factor for quantities, expressions or functions

Term.comment: created by Nick Juty and Lukas Endler - 17/9/08

Term.name: biochemical exponential coefficient

def.defstr: number used as an exponential factor for quantities, expressions or functions

Term.comment: created by Lukas Endler and Nick Juty - 17/9/08

Term.name: biochemical cooperative inhibition coefficient

def.defstr: The coefficient used to quantify the effect on inhibition constants of multiple inhibitors binding non-exclusively to the enzyme.

Term.comment: Created by Lukas Endler and Nick Juty - 18/9/08

Term.name: biochemical inhibitory proportionality coefficient

def.defstr: Coefficient that quantifies the effect on inhibition constants of either binding of multiple substrates or inhibitors.

Term.comment: Created by Lukas Endler and Nick Juty - 18/9/08

Term.name: biochemical cooperative inhibitor substrate coefficient

def.defstr: The coefficient that describes the proportional change of Ks or Ki when inhibitor or substrate is bound, respectively, to the enzyme.

Term.comment: Created by Nick Juty and Lukas Endler - 18/9/08.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by single competing substrate

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by a competing substrate (Sa) that binds to the free enzyme on the same binding site. The enzyme does not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: See Cornish-Bowden Fundementals of Enzyme Kinetics (3rd Edition 2004): Ch5.6, pp127.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for competitive inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzyme by product

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by a competing product (P) that binds to the free enzyme on the same binding site. The enzyme does not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.comment: See Cornish-Bowden Fundementals of Enzyme Kinetics (3rd Edition 2004): Ch2.8, pp55

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for inhibition of irreversible unireactant enzymes by single competing substrate with product inhibition

def.defstr: Inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by a competing substrate (Sa) that binds to the free enzyme on the same binding site, and competitive inhibition by a product (P) and an alternative product (Pa). The enzyme does not catalyse the reactions in both directions.

Term.name: switch value

def.defstr: A parameter value taken by a switch, which has a discrete set of values which can be alternated or switched between.

Term.comment: Created by NJ and LE for BioModels Database - 19/9/08

Term.name: boolean switch

def.defstr: A parameter that has precisely two discrete values which may be switched between. Usually for the boolean parameter these are indicated as '0 or 1' or 'True or False'.

Term.comment: Created by NJ and LE for Biomodels database - 19/9/08.

Term.name: steady state expression

def.defstr: A mathematical expression that describes a steady state situation

Term.comment: binding or interaction equilibria branch to hold mathematical expressions for equilibrium thermodynamics, electrochemical, binding, solution equilibria, complexes....

Term.name: equivalence

def.defstr: Term to signify those material or conceptual entities that are identical in some respect within a frame of reference

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - NJ and LE created for SBGN (equivalence arc - 2.6.9)

Term.name: production

def.defstr: Generation of a material or conceptual entity.

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - LE and NJ created for SBGN (production - 2.6.2)

Term.name: consumption

def.defstr: Decrease in amount of a material or conceptual entity.

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - LE and NJ created for SBGN (consumption - 2.6.1)

Term.name: encapsulating process

def.defstr: An aggregation of interactions and entities into a single process.

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - LE and NJ created for SBGN PD (submap - 2.4.3) Name and definition changed on November 18 2008 by Nicolas Le Novere

Term.name: uncertain process

def.defstr: An equivocal or conjectural process, whose existence is assumed but not proven.

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - NJ and LE created for SBGN (uncertain process - 2.5.3)

Term.name: omitted process

def.defstr: One or more processes that are not represented in certain representations or interpretations of a model.

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - LE and NJ created for SBGN (omitted process - 2.5.2)

Term.name: logical relationship

def.defstr: Relationship between entities (material or conceptual) and logical operators, or between logical operators themselves.

Term.comment: created 20/10/08 - LE and NJ. created for SBGN purposes (logical arc - 2.6.8)

Term.name: decarboxylation

def.defstr: A process in which a carboxyl group (COOH) is removed from a molecule as carbon dioxide.

Term.comment: created 21/10/08 - NJ

Term.name: decarbonylation

def.defstr: Removal of a carbonyl group (-C-O-) from a molecule, usually as carbon monoxide

Term.comment: created 21/10/08 - NJ

def.defstr: Removal of an amine group from a molecule, often under the addition of water

Term.name: transfer of a chemical group

def.defstr: Covalent reaction that results in the transfer of a chemical group from one molecule to another.

Term.comment: created 21/10/08

Term.name: transamination

def.defstr: The transfer of an amino group between two molecules. Commonly in biology this is restricted to reactions between an amino acid and an alpha-keto carbonic acid, whereby the reacting amino acid is converted into an alpha-keto acid, and the alpha-keto acid reactant into an amino acid.

Term.comment: created 21/10/08 - NJ modified to add more biological detail, to differentiate from alkylamino-de-amination.

def.defstr: Functional entity associated with or derived from a unit of inheritance.
A material entity that is responsible for a perturbing effect
An entity that can be measured quantitatively

Term.name: absolute inhibition

def.defstr: Control that precludes the execution of a process.

Term.comment: Created by Nicolas Le Novere for the needs of SBGN ER.

Term.name: biological activity

def.defstr: Effect of a biological entity on biological structures or processes.

Term.comment: Added for SBGN activity flow.

Term.name: interaction outcome

def.defstr: Entity that results from the interaction between other entities.

Term.comment: Added for SBGN entity relationships

Term.name: implicit compartment

def.defstr: A compartment whose existence is inferred due to the presence of known material entities which must be bounded, allowing the creation of material entity pools.

Term.comment: Created by Nicolas Le Novere on the demand of Frank Bergmann for SBGN purposes.

def.defstr: Control that always triggers the controlled process.

Term.name: biological activity

def.defstr: The potential action that a biological entity has on other entities. Example are enzymatic activity, binding activity etc.

Term.comment: Created by Nicolas Le Novere for SBGN purpose

def.defstr: The connectedness between entities as related by their position

Term.name: cis

def.defstr: Positional relationship between entities on the same strand (e.g. in DNA), or on the same side.

Term.comment: cis from the latin for 'same side'

Term.name: trans

def.defstr: Positional relationship between entities on different sides, or strands

Term.comment: From latin 'trans' meaning across, beyond, or through

def.defstr: One of the two values possible from a boolean switch, which equates to '1', 'on' or 'input'.
One of the two values possible from a boolean switch, which equates to '0', 'off' or 'no input'.
Non-covalent association between several independant complexes
Non-covalent association between portions of macromolecules that carry genetic information
Non-covalent association between several macromolecules
Non-covalent association between several simple chemicals

Term.name: isoinhibition constant

def.defstr: Inhibitory constant for the binding of a given ligand with an isomeric form of an enzyme.

Term.comment: see Segel Enzyme Kinetics (Wiley Classics Library, 1993), chapter 9 pg. 525

def.defstr: In reversible reactions this is the concentration of product that is required to achieve half activation or inhibition in Hill-type kinetics, in the absence of the substrate.
In reversible reactions this is the concentration of substrate that is required to achieve half activation or inhibition in Hill-type kinetics, in the absence of the product.

Term.name: reversible Hill-type enzymatic rate law

def.defstr: Reversible Hill-type kinetics represents the situation where a single substrate and product bind cooperatively and reversibly to the enzyme. Co-operativity is seen if the Hill coefficient (h) is greater than 1, indicating that the binding of one substrate (or product) molecule facilitates the binding of the next. The opposite effect is evident with a coefficient less than 1.

Term.comment: SF tracker (2912726) - name change to include 'enzymatic'.

def.defstr: Reversible Hill-type kinetics in the presence of at least one modifier whose binding is affected by the presence of the substrate or product.

Term.name: modulated reversible Hill-type rate law with one modifier

def.defstr: The modifier can be either an activator or inhibitor depending on the value of alpha (activator for values larger than 1, inhibitor for values smaller than 1; no effect if exactly 1). This reflects the effect of the presence of substrate and product on the binding of the modifier. The equation, derived by Hofmeyr and Cornish-Bowden (Comput. Appl. Biosci. 13, 377 - 385 (1997)

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell. The equation was originally derived by Hofmeyr and Cornish-Bowden (Comput. Appl. Biosci. 13, 377 - 385 (1997).

Term.name: modulated reversible Hill-type rate law with two modifiers
