def.defstr: The modifiers can be either activators or inhibitors depending on the values of and alpha (activators for values larger than 1, inhibitors for values smaller than 1; no effect if exactly 1). The assumption is that the binding of one modifier affects the binding of the second. Modifiers are assumed to bind at different sites. The synergetic effects of the two modifiers depend on the parameter alpha (if unity then they are independent; if zero they compete for the same binding site). and reflect the effect of the presence of substrate and product on the binding of modifier A or modifier B. alphaA and alphaB factors account for the effect of substrate and product binding on the binding of modifier A and modifier B respectively. alphaAB accounts for the interaction of the modifiers on each others binding. (if < 1 Ma is inhibitor, if > 1 activator) alpha_2 : factor accounting for the effect of S and P on the binding of Mb (if < 1 Mb is inhibitor, if > 1 activator) alpha_3 : factor accounting for interaction of Ma to Mb binding to the enzyme (and v. v.).

Term.comment: definition modified from WebCell. Equation originally derived by Hofmeyr and Cornish-Bowden (Comput. Appl. Biosci. 13, 377 - 385 (1997)).

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for multireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reactions with 2 or more substrates or products

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for modulated unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Kinetics of enzymes that react with one substance, and whose activity may be positively or negatively modulated.

Term.name: unmodulated reversible Hill-type rate law

def.defstr: Reversible equivalent of Hill kinetics, where substrate and product bind co-operatively to the enzyme. A Hill coefficient (h) of greater than 1 indicates positive co-operativity between substrate and product, while h values below 1 indicate negative co-operativity.

Term.comment: definition modified from WebCell

Term.name: irreversible Michaelis Menten rate law for two substrates

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law for an irreversible reaction involving two substrates and one product.

Enzymatic rate law for a reaction involving two substrates and two products. The products P and then Q are released strictly in order, while the substrates are bound strictly in the order A and then B.
Enzymatic rate for a reaction involving two substrates and one product. The substrates A and then B are bound strictly in order.
Enzymatic rate law for a reaction with one substrate and two products. The products P and then Q are released in the strict order P and then Q.

Term.name: Ping Pong Bi-Bi mechanism rate law

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law for a reaction involving two substrates and two products. The first product (P) is released after the first substrate (A) has been bound. The second product (Q) is released after the second substrate (B) has been bound.

Term.name: reversible Iso Uni-Uni

def.defstr: Enzyme catalysed reaction involving one substrate and one product. Unlike the reversible uni-uni mechanism (SBO:0000326), the mechanism assumes an enzyme intermediate. Therefore, the free enzyme generated after the release of product from enzyme-product complex is not the same form as that which bind the substrate to form enzyme-substrate complex. Some permeases are thought to follow this mechanism, such that isomerization in the membrane may be accomplished through re-orientation in the membrane.

Term.comment: modified from Webcell

def.defstr: The reversible equivalent of the Henri-Michaelis-Menten rate law (SBO:0000029).
Enzyme catalysed reaction involving one substrate and one product. It is a modification of SBO:0000326 that directly incorporates the equilibrium constant in the rate law.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible allosteric inhibition

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law which follows from the allosteric concerted model (symmetry model or MWC model).This states that enzyme subunits can assume one of two conformational states (relaxed or tense), and that the state of one subunit is shared or enforced on the others. The binding of a ligand to a site other than that bound by the substrate (active site) can shift the conformation from one state to the other. L represents the equilibrium constant between active and inactive states of the enzyme, and n represents the number of binding sites for the substrate and inhibitor.

Term.comment: Monod-Wyman-Changeaux model - see Monod et. al., J. Mol. Biol. 12: 88-118, 1965.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for mixed-type inhibition of reversible enzymes by mutually exclusive inhibitors

def.defstr: Reversible inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by inhibitors that can bind to the enzyme-substrate complex and to the free enzyme with the same equilibrium constant. The inhibitor is noncompetitive with the substrate.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple reversible non-competitive inhibition of unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Reversible inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor that can bind to the enzyme-substrate complex and to the free enzyme with the same equilibrium constant. The inhibitor is noncompetitive with the substrate.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible essential activation

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the free enzyme, in the absence of the activator, is unable to bind substrate and has no activity.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible mixed activation

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the activator enhances the rate of reaction through specific and catalytic effects, which increase the apparent limiting rate and decrease apparent Michaelis constant. The activator can bind reversibly both the free enzyme and enzyme-substrate complex, while the substrate can bind only to enzyme-activator complex. Catalytic activity is seen only when enzyme, substrate and activator are complexed.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell TODO : potentiator -> activator?

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible substrate activation

def.defstr: This enzymatic rate law is available only for irreversible reactions, with one substrate and one product. There is a second binding site for the enzyme which, when occupied, activates the enzyme. Substrate binding at either site can occur at random.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irrreversible mixed activation

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the activator enhances the rate of reaction through specific and catalytic effects, which increase the apparent limiting rate and decrease apparent Michaelis constant. The activator can bind irreversibly both free enzyme and enzyme-substrate complex, while the substrate can bind only to enzyme-activator complex. Catalytic activity is seen only when enzyme, substrate and activator are complexed.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell TODO : potentiator -> activator?

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible catalytic activation with one activator

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where an activator enhances the rate of reaction by increasing the apparent limiting rate; The reversible binding of the activator to the enzyme-substrate complex is required for enzyme catalytic activity (to generate the product).

Term.comment: Definition adapted from WebCell TODO : potentiator -> activator

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible specific activation

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law for one substrate, one product and one modifier which acts as an activator. The activator enhances the rate of reaction by decreasing the apparent Michaelis constant. The activator reversibly binds to the enzyme before the enzyme can bind the substrate.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell TODO : potentiator -> activator?

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible catalytic activation with one activator

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where an activator enhances the rate of reaction by increasing the apparent limiting rate; The activator binding to the enzyme-substrate complex (irreversibly) is required for enzyme catalytic activity (to generate the product).

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell TODO : potentiator -> activator?

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible specific activation

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law for one substrate, one product and one modifier which acts as an activator. The activator enhances the rate of reaction by decreasing the apparent Michaelis constant. The activator must bind to the enzyme before the enzyme can bind the substrate.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell. TODO : Possibly replace potentiator term for something more specific (activator?)

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible reactions with competitive inhibition

def.defstr: This enzymatic rate law involves one substrate, one product and one or more modifiers. The modifiers act as competitive inhibitors of the substrate at the enzyme binding site; The modifiers (inhibitors) reversibly bound to the enzyme block access to the substrate. The inhibitors have the effect of increasing the apparent Km, and bind exclusively to the enzymes.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible competitive inhibition by one inhibitor

def.defstr: This enzymatic rate law involves one substrate, one product and one modifier. The modifier acts as a competitive inhibitor with the substrate at the enzyme binding site; The modifier (inhibitor) reversibly bound to the enzyme blocks access to the substrate. The inhibitor has the effect of increasing the apparent Km.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible empirical allosteric inhibition by one inhibitor

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the reversible binding of one ligand decreases the affinity for substrate at other active sites. The ligand does not bind the same site as the substrate on the enzyme. This is an empirical equation, where n represents the Hill coefficient.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible substrate inhibition

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the substrate for an enzyme also acts as a reversible inhibitor. This may entail a second (non-active) binding site for the enzyme. The inhibition constant is then the dissociation constant for the substrate from this second site.

Term.comment: Definition adapted from WebCell.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible substrate inhibition

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the substrate for an enzyme also acts as an irreversible inhibitor. This may entail a second (non-active) binding site for the enzyme. The inhibition constant is then the dissociation constant for the substrate from this second site.

Term.comment: Definition adapted from WebCell.

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for reversible unireactant enzyme with a single hyperbolic modulator

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the modifier can act as an activator or inhibitor, depending upon the values of the kinetic constants. The modifier can bind reversibly to all forms of the enzyme and all enzyme-substrate complexes are reactive. 'a' represents the ratio of dissociation constant of the elementary step Enzyme-Substrate complex + Modifier = Enzyme-Substrate-Modifier complex over that of Enzyme + Modifier = Enzyme-Modifier complex. 'b' represents ratio of the rate constant of elementary step Enzyme-Substrate-Modifier complex -> Enzyme-Modifier complex + Product over that of Enzyme-Substrate complex -> Enzyme + Product.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for irreversible unireactant enzyme with a single hyperbolic modulator

def.defstr: Enzymatic rate law where the modifier can act as an activator or inhibitor, depending upon the values of the kinetic constants. The modifier can bind irreversibly to all forms of the enzyme and all enzyme-substrate complexes are reactive. 'a' represents the ratio of dissociation constant of the elementary step Enzyme-Substrate complex + Modifier = Enzyme-Substrate-Modifier complex) over that of Enzyme + Modifier = Enzyme-Modifier complex. 'b' represents ratio of the rate constant of elementary step Enzyme-Substrate-Modifier complex -> Enzyme-Modifier complex + Product over that of Enzyme-Substrate complex -> Enzyme + Product.

Term.comment: Definition modified from WebCell

Term.name: enzymatic rate law for simple uncompetitive inhibition of reversible unireactant enzymes

def.defstr: Reversible inhibition of a unireactant enzyme by one inhibitor, which binds to the enzyme-substrate complex. The inhibitor is uncompetitive with the substrate.
Substance that accelerates the velocity of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed or transformed.

A substance that accelerates the velocity of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed or transformed, by lowering the free energy of the transition state. The substance acting as a catalyst is an enzyme.
A substance that is absolutely required for occurrence and stimulation of a reaction.
An activator which is not necessary for an enzymatic reaction, but whose presence will further increase enzymatic activity.
The biochemical potential of a substance measured at standard concentrations and under standard conditions.

Term.name: state variable assignment

def.defstr: Assignment of a state or a value to a state variable, characteristic or property, of a biological entity.

Term.comment: For instance assignment of the state "phosphorylated" to a phosphorylation site, or the state "open" to a channel pore.

Term.name: spatial measure

def.defstr: The measurable dimensions of an object which are minimally required to define the space that an object occupies.

Term.comment: should correspond to spatial dimension in OPB (child of physical dimension)

def.defstr: The length of an object is the longest measurable distance between its extremities.
The area of an object is a quantity expressing its two-dimensional size, usually part or all of its surface.
A quantity representing the three-dimensional space occupied by all or part of an object.
An entity that is a subset of another entity or object.

Term.name: mass fraction

def.defstr: For a given substance, A, its mass fraction (x A) is defined as the ratio of its mass (m A) to the total mass (m total) in which it is present, where the sum of all mass fractions is equal to 1. This provides a means to express concentration in a dimensionless size.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_fraction_(chemistry)

Term.name: molal concentration of an entity

def.defstr: Molality denotes the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent (not solution). The term molal solution is used as a shorthand for a "one molal solution", i.e. a solution which contains one mole of the solute per kilogram of the solvent. The SI unit for molality is mol/kg.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molality#Molality

Term.name: molar concentration of an entity

def.defstr: Molarity, or molar concentration, denotes the number of moles of a given substance per litre of solution. The unit of measure of molarity is mol/L, molar, or the capital letter M as an abbreviated form.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molarity

Term.name: denotement

def.defstr: Term to signify where a material or conceptual entity is represented or denoted by a symbol or by some other abbreviated form.

Term.comment: created for SBGN purposes, at the suggestion of NLN, to represent the SBGN glyph 'tag' ( see SBGN specification 2.3.9 Glyph: Tag)

def.defstr: Mathematical function commonly used in biological modeling, which enable simplification of more complex expressions

Term.name: periodic forcing function

def.defstr: Function that enables the modeling of cyclic inputs with on and off phases, such as the light and dark phases in circadian rhythm. It includes parameters for the 'on' period (Tp), the cycle period (Tc), and the time taken to move or 'ramp' between 'on' and 'off' stages (Tw). Theta0 and Theta1 represent the minimal offset and maximal values of 'on' stage, respectively. Small values of Tw result in step-like changes. Phi is the time of the phase shift offset. In the case of light forcing, Tp represents 'light' period, Tc the cycle period, and Tw the 'twilight' timescale. Theta0 is the light value at the off state, and Theta1 the additional value at the on phase.

Term.comment: Modified bvars to refer to more specific terms as requested [SF bug #3477686]. Request submitted by Akman et al., "Working Title: SBML functions for periodic light forcing in models of circadian clocks" - function recoded by LE

def.defstr: The period is the duration of one cycle in a repeating event. [wikipedia]
The measurable amount of time by which a periodic or cyclic is shifted or offset from defined reference point.
The product of the Michaelis constants, to the power of their respective stoichiometric coefficients, for either substrates or products.

Term.name: powered product of substrate Michaelis constants

def.defstr: The product of the substrate Michaelis constants, to the power of their respective stoichiometric coefficients.

Term.name: powered product of product Michaelis constants

def.defstr: The product of the product Michaelis constants, to the power of their respective stoichiometric coefficients.

Term.name: stoichiometric coefficient

def.defstr: The stoichiometric coefficient represents the degree to which a chemical species participates in a reaction. It corresponds to the number of molecules of a reactant that are consumed or produced with each occurrence of a reaction event.

Term.comment: adapted from wikipedia [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stoichiometry]

Term.name: geometric mean rate constant

def.defstr: The geometric mean turnover rate of an enzyme in either forward or backward direction for a reaction, measured per second.

Term.comment: Liebermeister W. and Klipp E. (2006), Bringing metabolic networks to life: convenience rate law and thermodynamic constraints, Theoretical Biology and Medical Modelling 3:41.

Term.name: forward geometric mean rate constant

def.defstr: The geometric mean turnover rate of an enzyme in the forward direction for a reaction, measured per second.

Term.comment: Liebermeister W. and Klipp E. (2006), Bringing metabolic networks to life: convenience rate law and thermodynamic constraints, Theoretical Biology and Medical Modelling 3:41.

Term.name: reverse geometric mean rate constant

def.defstr: The geometric mean turnover rate of an enzyme in the reverse direction for a reaction, measured per second.

Term.comment: Liebermeister W. and Klipp E. (2006), Bringing metabolic networks to life: convenience rate law and thermodynamic constraints, Theoretical Biology and Medical Modelling 3:41.

def.defstr: The minimal velocity observed under defined conditions, which may or may not include the presence of an effector. For example in an inhibitory system, this would be the residual velocity observed under full inhibition. In non-essential activation, this would be the velocity in the absence of any activator.
The ratio of the basal activity to the maximal velocity of a reaction. The values range between 0 and 1.
Function which ranges from 0 to 1, to describe the relative activation or inhibition of a reaction or process, actual or conceptual.
Function which ranges from 0 to 1, to describe the relative activation of a reaction or process, actual or conceptual.
Function which ranges from 0 to 1, to describe the relative inhibition of a reaction or process, actual or conceptual.
Number of molecules which are generated by an enzyme.

Term.name: diffusion coefficient

def.defstr: A proportionality constant representing the amount of substance diffusing across a unit area through a unit concentration gradient in unit time. The higher the diffusion coefficient (of one substance with respect to another), the faster they diffuse into each other. This coefficient has an SI unit of m²/s (length²/time).

Term.comment: see also: http://goldbook.iupac.org/D01719.html http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_diffusivity

Term.name: amplitude

def.defstr: Amplitude is the magnitude of change in the oscillating variable, with each oscillation, within an oscillating system.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amplitude

def.defstr: A spatial region of an entity that confers a function

Term.name: binding site

def.defstr: A specific domain of a spatio-temporal entity to which another spatio-temporal entity is able to bind, forming chemical bonds.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binding_site

def.defstr: A catalytic site is the region which confers specificity of a substrate for the binding entity, and where specific reactions take place in the conversion of the substrate to the product.

Term.name: transmembrane domain

def.defstr: A transmembrane domain is any three-dimensional protein structure which is thermodynamically stable in a membrane. This may be a single alpha helix, a stable complex of several transmembrane alpha helices, a transmembrane beta barrel, a beta-helix of gramicidin A, or any other structure.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmembrane_domain

def.defstr: A parameter that has three discrete values which may be alternated between.
Value which ranges from 0 to 1, to describe the relative activity of a process or reaction.

Term.name: genetic interaction

def.defstr: A phenomenon whereby an observed phenotype, qualitative or quantative, is not explainable by the simple additive effects of the individual gene pertubations alone. Genetic interaction between perturbed genes is usually expected to generate a 'defective' phenotype. The level of defectiveness is often used to sub-classify this phenomenon.

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_interaction

def.defstr: Genetic suppression is said to have occurred when the phenotypic effect of an initial mutation in a gene is less severe, or entirely negated, by a subsequent mutation.
Genetic enhancement is said to have occurred when the phenotypic effect of an initial mutation in a gene is made increasingly severe by a subsequent mutation.
Synthetic lethality is said to have occurred where gene mutations, each of which map to a separate locus, fail to complement in an offspring to correct a phenotype, as would be expected.

The numerical quantification of an entity pool. This may be expressed as, for example, the number of molecules or the number of moles of identical entities of which an specific entity pool is comprised.
The mass that comprises an entity pool.
Amount of enzyme present per unit of volume. The participant role 'enzymatic catalyst' is defined in SBO:0000460.
Amount, expressed as a mass, of an enzyme. The participant role 'enzymatic catalyst' is defined in SBO:0000460.

Amount, expressed as a number, of a specific enzyme comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'enzymatic catalyst' is defined in SBO:0000460.

The amount, expressed as a number, of a specific reactant comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'reactant' is defined in SBO:0000010.
The amount of a specific entity pool reactant present per unit of volume. The participant role 'reactant' is defined in SBO:0000010.
The amount, expressed as a mass, of a specific reactant entity pool. The participant role 'reactant' is defined in SBO:0000010.

The amount, expressed as a number, of a specific product comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'product' is defined in SBO:0000011.
The amount of a specific entity pool product present per unit of volume. The participant role 'product' is defined in SBO:0000011.
The amount, expressed as a mass, of a specific product entity pool. The participant role 'product' is defined in SBO:0000011.

The amount, expressed as a number, of a specific substrate comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'substrate' is defined in SBO:0000015.
The amount of a specific entity pool substrate present per unit of volume. The participant role 'substrate' is defined in SBO:0000015.
The amount, expressed as a mass, of a specific substrate entity pool. The participant role 'substrate' is defined in SBO:0000015.

The amount, expressed as a number, of a specific modifier comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'modifier' is defined in SBO:0000019.
The amount of a specific modifier entity pool present per unit of volume. The participant role 'modifier' is defined in SBO:0000019.
The amount, expressed as a mass, of a specific modifier entity pool. The participant role 'modifier' is defined in SBO:0000019.

The amount, expressed as a number, of a specific inhibitor comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'inhibitor' is defined in SBO:0000020.
The amount of a specific inhibitor entity pool present per unit of volume. The participant role 'inhibitor' is defined in SBO:0000020.
The amount, expressed as a mass, of a specific inhibitor entity pool. The participant role 'inhibitor' is defined in SBO:0000020.

The amount, expressed as a number, of a specific activator comprising an entity pool. This may be expressed, for example, as the number of molecules, or the number of moles. The participant role 'activator' is defined in SBO:0000459.
The amount of a specific activator entity pool present per unit of volume. The participant role 'activator' is defined in SBO:0000459.
The amount, expressed as a mass, of a specific activator entity pool. The participant role 'activator' is defined in SBO:0000459.

Term.name: protein complex formation

def.defstr: The process by which two or more proteins interact non-covalently to form a protein complex (SBO:0000297).

Term.comment: see also GO:0006461 (protein complex assembly)

Term.name: modular rate law
Term.comment: under review: Liebermeister, Uhlendorf and Klipp (2010), "Modular rate laws for enzymatic reactions: thermodynamics, elasticities, and implementation." journal, xyz:abc-def).

Term.name: common modular rate law

def.defstr: The common modular rate law is a generalised form of reversible Michaelis Menten kinetics, using a denominator where each binding state of the enzyme is represented. It is assumed that substrates and products bind independently and randomly, and that substrates and products cannot be bound at the same time.

Term.comment: under review: Liebermeister, Uhlendorf and Klipp (2010), "Modular rate laws for enzymatic reactions: thermodynamics, elasticities, and implementation." journal, xyz:abc-def).

Term.name: direct binding modular rate law

def.defstr: The direct binding modular rate law makes the assumption that both substrates and products bind simultaneously and in a single step, hence the total binding states possible enumerate to 3; nothing bound, substrates bound, and products bound. Substrates and products cannot be bound at the same time.

Term.comment: under review: Liebermeister, Uhlendorf and Klipp (2010), "Modular rate laws for enzymatic reactions: thermodynamics, elasticities, and implementation." journal, xyz:abc-def).

Term.name: simultaneous binding modular rate law

def.defstr: The simultaneous binding modular rate law makes the assumption that substrates and products can be bound simultaneously, and in any combination.

Term.comment: under review: Liebermeister, Uhlendorf and Klipp (2010), "Modular rate laws for enzymatic reactions: thermodynamics, elasticities, and implementation." journal, xyz:abc-def).

Term.name: power-law modular rate law

def.defstr: For the power-law rate law, the denominator is set to be a constant, and the rate law does not saturate.

Term.comment: under review: Liebermeister, Uhlendorf and Klipp (2010), "Modular rate laws for enzymatic reactions: thermodynamics, elasticities, and implementation." journal, xyz:abc-def).

Term.name: force-dependent modular rate law

def.defstr: Modular rate law where the D term is given by the square root of the product of terms (c/KM)^m where c, KM, and m denote the concentrations, Michaelis constants, and molecularities, respectively, and the product is taken over all reactants and products involved in the reaction.

Term.comment: under review: Liebermeister, Uhlendorf and Klipp (2010), "Modular rate laws for enzymatic reactions: thermodynamics, elasticities, and implementation." journal, xyz:abc-def).

Term.name: specific activator

def.defstr: An essential activator that affects the apparent value of the specificity constant. Mechanistically, the activator would need to be bound before reactant and product binding can take place.

Term.comment: see also: http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/kinetics/ek7.html#p7

Term.name: catalytic activator

def.defstr: An essential activator that affects the apparent value of the catalytic constant.

Term.comment: see also: http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/kinetics/ek7.html#p7

Term.name: binding activator

def.defstr: An essential activator that affects the apparent value of the Michaelis constant(s).

Term.comment: see also: http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/kinetics/ek7.html#p7

Term.name: partial inhibitor

def.defstr: Substance that, when bound, decreases enzymatic activity to a lower, nonzero value, without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction, and without sterically hindering the interaction between reactants. The enzyme-inhibitor complex does retain some basal level of activity.

Term.comment: see also: http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/kinetics/ek7.html#p7

Term.name: complete inhibitor

def.defstr: Substance that, when bound, completely negates enzymatic activity, without itself being consumed or transformed by the reaction, and without sterically hindering the interaction between reactants. The inhibitor binds to all enzyme species independently and with the same affinity, completely inhibiting any enzymatic activity.

Term.comment: see also: http://www.chem.qmul.ac.uk/iubmb/kinetics/ek7.html#p7

def.defstr: A parameter that represents the permeability of an ion channel with respect to a particular ion.

Term.name: probabilistic parameter

def.defstr: A quantitative parameter that represents a probability value, assigned to a specific event.

Term.comment: term request by Benedetta Baldi, see SF#3132390

Term.name: fraction of an entity pool

def.defstr: A ratio that represents the quantity of a defined constituent entity over the total number of all constituent entities present.

Term.comment: see also http://goldbook.iupac.org/A00296.html created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3154729]

Term.name: mole fraction

def.defstr: The number of moles of a constituent entity, divided by the total number of all constituent entities present in a system.

Term.comment: see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mole_fraction; created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3154729]

Term.name: basic reproductive ratio

def.defstr: An epidemiological term representing the mean number of secondary cases which result from a single infection, where the population under consideration has no immunity, and no intervention is performed.

Term.comment: see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number; created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3154757]

Term.name: protein aggregate

def.defstr: A nonspecific coalescence of misfolded proteins which may or may not form a precipitate, depending upon particle size.

Term.comment: in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3160919]

def.defstr: Supplementary information relating to a primary item of data, traditionally termed 'data about data'. It can describe, for example, the location or type of the data, or its relationship to other data.

Term.name: systems description parameter

def.defstr: A value, numerical or symbolic, that defines certain characteristics of systems or system functions, or is necessary in their derivation.

Term.comment: Modified as part of the ontology refactoring' process [SF bug #3172586].

Term.name: qualitative systems description parameter

def.defstr: A non-numerical value that defines certain characteristics of systems or system functions.

Term.comment: Modified as part of ontology 'refactoring' process [SF bug #3172586].

Term.name: boolean logical framework

def.defstr: Equationally defined algebraic framework usually interpreted as a two-valued logic using the basic Boolean operations (conjunction, disjunction and negation), together with the constants '0' and '1' denoting false and true values, respectively.

Term.name: multi-valued logical framework

def.defstr: Extension of the boolean logical framework which associates a defined number of possible integer values (states) with the variables.

Term.name: fuzzy logical framework

def.defstr: Extension of the Boolean logical framework which allows intermediate or undetermined values for the logical variables.

Term.name: annotation

def.defstr: Supplementary information that does not modify the semantics of the presented information.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]; see also [SBGN ER 'Annotation']

Term.name: controlled short label

def.defstr: The use of an abbreviated name, taken from a controlled vocabulary of terms, which is used to represent some information about the entity to which it is attached.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]; see also [SBGN ER 'Unit of information']

Term.name: reference annotation

def.defstr: Additional information that supplements existing data, usually in a document, by providing a link to more detailed information, which is held externally, or elsewhere.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]

Term.name: bibliographical reference

def.defstr: An annotation which directs one to information contained within a published body of knowledge, usually a book or scientific journal.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]

Term.name: database cross reference

def.defstr: An annotation which directs one to information contained within a database.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]

Term.name: controlled annotation

def.defstr: Annotation which complies with the full set of defined rules in its construction.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]

Term.name: uncontrolled annotation

def.defstr: Annotation which does not comply with, or is not restricted by, any rules in its construction. Examples would include free text annotations.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]

Term.name: embedded annotation

def.defstr: Annotation that directly incorporates information into the body of a document.

Term.comment: refer to [SF req #3172596]

Term.name: specific activity

def.defstr: A measure of enzyme activity under standard conditions, at a specific substrate concentration (usually saturation), expressed as the amount of product formed per unit time, per amount of enzyme. This is often expressed as micromol per min per mg, rather than the less practical official unit, Katal (1 mol per second).

Term.name: enzyme activity

def.defstr: A measure of the amount of active enzyme present, expressed under specified conditions. This is often expressed as micromol per min (also known as enzyme unit, U), rather than the less practical official SI unit, Katal (1 mol per second). Enzyme activity normally refers to the natural substrate for the enzyme, but can also be given for standardised substrates such as gelatin, where it is then referred to as GDU (Gelatin Digesting Units).

Term.comment: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enzyme_assay#Enzyme_activity

Term.name: mass action rate law for first order irreversible reactions, single essential stimulator, continuous scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme in which the reaction velocity is direct proportional to the activity or concentration of a single molecular species. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. The change of a product quantity is proportional to the quantity of the stimulator. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.comment: created on request of LE; [SF req #3325167]

Term.name: mass action rate law for first order irreversible reactions, single essential stimulator, discrete scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme in which the reaction velocity is direct proportional to the activity or quantity of a single molecular species. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. The change of a product quantity is proportional to the quantity of the stimulator. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a discrete framework.

Term.comment: created on request of LE; [SF req #3325167]

Term.name: mass action like rate law for second order irreversible reactions, one reactant, one essential stimulator

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from a reactant and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of the reactant and the stimulator activities. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactant from the products. The change of a product quantity is proportional to the quantity of the reactant and the stimulator.

Term.comment: created on request of LE; [SF req #3325167]

Term.name: mass action like rate law for second order irreversible reactions, one reactant, one essential stimulator, continuous scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from a reactant and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of the reactant and the stimulator activities. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactant from the products. The change of a product quantity is proportional to the quantity of the reactant and the stimulator. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.comment: created on request of LE; [SF req #3325167]

Term.name: mass action like rate law for second order irreversible reactions, one reactant, one essential stimulator, discrete scheme

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from a reactant and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of the reactant and the stimulator quantities. The reaction scheme does not include any reverse process that creates the reactant from the products. The change of a product quantity is proportional to the quantity of the reactant and the stimulator. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a discrete framework.

Term.comment: created on request of LE; [SF req #3325167]

Term.name: systems description constant

def.defstr: A physical constant that is required in the calculation of a system parameter.

Term.comment: see also: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_constant

Term.name: relative permeability

def.defstr: The permeability of an ion through a channel or membrane expressed in relation to the reference ion, which is given the value 1. For example, if a membrane is most permeable to K+, then that is assigned the reference permeability value of 1, and the value for Na+ may be 0.05.

Term.comment: created to allow incorporation of terms requested [SF req #3293425]

Term.name: universal gas constant

def.defstr: A physical constant featured in many fundamental equations in the physical sciences. It is equivalent to the Boltzmann constant, but expressed in units of energy per temperature increment per mole (rather than energy per temperature increment per particle). It has the value 8.314 J.K-1.mol-1 and is denoted by the symbol R.

Term.name: Faraday constant

def.defstr: Named after Michael Faraday, it is the magnitude of electric charge per mole of electrons. It has the value 96,485.3365 C/mol (Coulombs per Mole), and the symbol F.

Term.comment: modified from wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_constant; see also: OPB_00089 (Ontology of Physics in Biology); created in response: [SF req #3293425]

Term.name: Goldman equation

def.defstr: Expression to determine the equilibrium potential (membrane potential) across a cellular membrane, taking into consideration all the ions on either side of the membrane, and their permeability through the membrane. Permeability values are often recorded as relative permeability, with the most permeable ion being given a reference value of 1. The unit of measure for membrane potential is Volts, though values are typically reported as millivolts (mV). The given formula represents the voltage equation for 'C' monovalent cations, and 'A' monovalent anions, assuming that C is the most permeable, and thereby reporting all other permeabilities as a proportion of the reference value, of 1. 'P' represents the membrane permeability of C (assumed reference molecule, value 1); 'p', the relative permeability of each non-reference molecule; 'C', the external monovalent cation; 'c', the internal monovalent cation concentration; 'A', the external monovalent anion; 'a', the internal monovalent anion concentration; 'R', the universal gas constant; 'T', the temperature in Kelvin; 'F' the Faraday constant.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3293425]

Term.name: Nernst potential

def.defstr: The membrane potential at which there is no net flow of an ions across a biological membrane. In a single ion system, this is equal to the equilibrium potential and can be calculated from the Nernst equation. It takes into consideration the charge, z, of the ion, as well as its concentration inside (x) and outside (X) the membrane.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3293425]

Term.name: thermodynamic parameter

def.defstr: Parameters used in the study of thermodynamics, a physical science that pertains to the relationship between heat and other forms of energy such as 'work done' in material bodies.

Term.comment: created for [SF req #3286595]

Term.name: enthalpy

def.defstr: A thermodynamic potential whose natural variables are entropy (S) and pressure (p). The enthalpy of a system, measured in Joules (J), is defined as H = U + pV (where H is enthalpy, U is the internal energy, p is the pressure at the system boundary, and V is the system volume). symbol: H

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram; see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enthalpy

Term.name: enthalpy change

def.defstr: Change in enthalpy observed in the constituents of a thermodynamic system when undergoing a transformation or chemical reaction. This is the preferred way of expressing the energy changes to a system at constant pressure, since enthalpy itself cannot be directly measured. The enthalpy change is positive in endothermic reactions, negative in exothermic reactions, and is defined as the difference between the final and initial enthalpy of the system under study: ΔH = Hf - Hi. The standard unit of measure is J. Symbol: ΔH

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram

Term.name: standard enthalpy of formation

def.defstr: The enthalpy change observed in a constituent of a thermodynamic system when one mole of a compound, in its standard state, is formed from its elementary antecedents, in their standard state(s), under standard conditions (1 bar). The standard unit of measure is kJ/mol. Symbol: DeltaHf0, DeltafH0

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]

Term.name: standard enthalpy of reaction

def.defstr: The enthalpy change observed in a constituent of a thermodynamic system when one mole of substance reacts completely, under standard conditions (1 bar). The standard unit of measure is kJ/mol. Symbol: DeltaHr0, DeltarH0

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595];

Term.name: entropy

def.defstr: A thermodynamic property which acts as a measure of the state of disorder of a system. Its natural variables are the internal energy (U) and the volume (V). It is defined by dS = (1/T)dU + (p/T)dV. The second law of thermodynamics states that in an isolated system, natural processes tend to increase in disorder or entropy. The standard unit of measure is Joules per Kelvin (J/K). symbol: S

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram; see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy

Term.name: entropy change

def.defstr: The increase or decrease of the entropy of a system. For values greater than zero, there is an implied increase in the disorder of a system, for example during a reaction, and decreased disorder where the values are less than zero. The entropy change of a process is defined as the initial system entropy value minus the final entropy value: DeltaS = Sf - Si. The standard unit of measure is J/K. symbol: DeltaS

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram

Term.name: standard entropy of reaction

def.defstr: The entropy change observed in a thermodynamic system when one mole of substance reacts completely, under standard conditions (1 bar). The standard unit of measure is kJ/(mol K). This can be calculated using the entropies for products and reactants: DeltaS(reaction)=sum DeltaS (products) - sum DeltaS reactants. The standard unit of measure is kJ/(mol K). symbol: DeltaSro

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram

Term.name: standard entropy of formation

def.defstr: The change in entropy associated with the formation of one mole of a substance from its elements in their standard states under standard conditions (1 bar). The standard unit of measure is kJ/(mol K). symbol: DeltaSfo

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram

Term.name: Gibbs free energy

def.defstr: A thermodynamic potential that measures the useful work obtainable from a thermodynamic system at constant pressure and temperature. Its natural variables are pressure (p) and temperature (T) and the definition is: G = H - TS. Gibbs free energy is minimised when a system reaches equilibrium at constant pressure and temperature. The standard unit of measure is kJ/mol. symbol: G

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595]; assistance from Wolfram; see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_free_energy

Term.name: Gibbs free energy change

def.defstr: The increase or decrease of the Gibbs free energy of a system. During a reaction, this is equal to the change in enthalpy of the system minus the change in the product of the temperature times the entropy of the system: ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS. A negative value indicates that the reaction will be favoured and will release energy. The magnitude of the value indicates how far the reaction is from equilibrium, where there will be no free energy change. The standard unit of measure is kJ/mol. Symbol: ΔG.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595];

Term.name: standard Gibbs free energy of formation

def.defstr: The change in Gibbs free energy associated with the formation of 1 mole of substance from elements in their standard states under standard conditions (1 bar). For aqueous solutions, each solute must be present in 1M concentration. The standard unit of measure is kJ/mol. Symbol: ΔGf°.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595];

Term.name: standard Gibbs free energy of reaction

def.defstr: The Gibbs free energy change observed in a thermodynamic system when one mole of substance reacts completely, under standard conditions (1 bar). For aqueous solutions, each solute must be present in 1M concentration. The standard unit of measure is kJ/mol. Symbol: ΔG°.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3286595];

Term.name: temporal offset

def.defstr: A duration of time after which a phase shift occurs.

Term.comment: Created as a consequence of term refinement [SF bug #3477686]

def.defstr: The total length of time over which a model is simulated, where the time scale is indicated within the model simulation.
A conceptualisation of time which is intrinsic to a mathematical model, and which can be used to describe other variables or parameters of the model.

Term.name: transcellular membrane influx reaction

def.defstr: A transport reaction which results in the entry of the transported entity, into the cell.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3513165]

Term.name: transcellular membrane efflux reaction

def.defstr: A transport reaction which results in the removal of the transported entity from the cell.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3513165].

Term.name: genetic production

def.defstr: A composite biochemical process through which a gene sequence is fully converted into mature gene products. These gene products may include RNA species as well as proteins, and the process encompasses all intermediate steps required to generate the active form of the gene product.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3503788]; see also [xref: http://identifiers.org/obo.go/GO:0010467]

Term.name: promoter

def.defstr: A stretch of DNA upstream of a transcription start site, to which a promoter and other transcription factors may bind to initiate or regulate expression.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3503791]

Term.name: petri net transition

def.defstr: A process that can modify the state of petri net 'places'[SBO:0000593].

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3562973]; see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net

Term.name: discrete amount of an entity pool

def.defstr: A discrete value attributed to an entity pool.

Term.comment: create in partial response to [SF req #3562973]

Term.name: petri net place

def.defstr: A defined entity pool state which can be modified by a petri net transition [SBO:0000591].

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3562973]; see also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net

Term.name: neutral participant

def.defstr: A participant whose presence does not alter the velocity of a process or event.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3503716]

Term.name: dual-activity modifier

def.defstr: A modifier that can exhibit either inhibitory or stimulatory effects on a process depending on the context in which it occurs. For example, the observed effect may be dependent upon the concentration of the modifier.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3503716]

Term.name: modifier of unknown activity

def.defstr: A modifier whose activity is not known or has not been specified.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3503716]

Term.name: silencer

def.defstr: A silencer is a modifier which acts in a manner that completely prevents an event or process from occurring. For example, a silencer in gene expression is usually a transcription factor that binds a DNA sequence in such a way as to completely prevent the binding of RNA polymerase, and thus fully suppresses transcription.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3503716]

Term.name: promoter

def.defstr: A region of DNA to which various transcription factors and RNA polymerase must bind in order to initiate transcription for a gene.

Term.comment: created in response to SourceForge term request [SF req #3503716]

Term.name: port

def.defstr: A denotement that specifies a point of contact between variables or submodels in a hierarchical model.

Term.comment: created in response to request [SF req #3509733]

Term.name: input port

def.defstr: A connection point to an element in a model that indicates that the element's mathematical interpretation is defined outside the model.

Term.comment: created in response to request [SF req #3509733]

Term.name: output port

def.defstr: A connection point to an element in a model that indicates that the element's mathematical interpretation is defined within the model.

Term.comment: created in response to request [SF req #3509733]

Term.name: logical parameter

def.defstr: A parameter that takes only logical values.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3564480]

Term.name: side product

def.defstr: A substance that is produced in a chemical reaction but is not itself the primary product or focus of that reaction. Examples include, but are not limited to, currency compounds such as ATP, NADPH and protons.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3604202].

Term.name: side substrate

def.defstr: A substance that is consumed in a chemical reaction but is not itself the primary substrate or focus of that reaction. Examples include, but are not limited to, currency compounds such as ATP, NADPH and protons.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #3604202].

Term.name: high affinity receptor

def.defstr: A receptor where binding occurs through strong intermolecular forces such as Van der Waals, hydrogen bonds or ionic bonds.

Term.comment: created in response to SF#100

Term.name: low affinity receptor

def.defstr: A receptor where binding occurs through weak intermolecular forces.

Term.comment: created in response to SF#100

Term.name: dimer

def.defstr: A macromolecular complex composed of two monomeric units, which may or may not be identical. Monomers are usually non-covalently bound.

Term.comment: created in response to SF req #101

Term.name: homodimer

def.defstr: A macromolecular complex composed of precisely two identical monomeric units, which are usually non-covalently bound.

Term.comment: created in response to SF req #101

Term.name: heterodimer

def.defstr: A macromolecular complex composed of precisely two non-identical monomeric units, which are usually non-covalently bound.

Term.comment: created in response to SF req #101

def.defstr: A measure of the rate of growth of an organism, usually in culture. This can be expressed as increase in cell number or, more usually as an increase in dry weight of cells (grams), measured over a unit time period. Usually expressed as hour -1.

Term.name: effective catalytic rate

def.defstr: Under nutrient limited conditions, it may be assumed that enzymes are operating below their maximal capacity (Kcat). Keff represents the lumped turnover rate of a reaction, expressed in units per time.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #104]

Term.name: rate of reaction

def.defstr: The velocity at which a reaction occurs. This may be calculated through the accumulation of a product or consumption of a reactant, and expressed using entity concentrations or amounts per time interval. The rate of reaction may be influenced by temperature, pressure and other factors. Rate of reaction is often referred to as reaction rate or metabolic flux.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #105].

Term.name: reaction parameter

def.defstr: Parameters that pertain to chemical reactions.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #105].

Term.name: rate of reaction (concentration)

def.defstr: Rate of reaction expressed as a change in concentration over time.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #105].

Term.name: rate of reaction (amount)

def.defstr: Rate of reaction expressed as a change in enumerated quantity over time.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #105].

Term.name: extent of reaction

def.defstr: The extent of a reaction is a measure of how far a reaction has proceeded towards equilibrium. It is denoted by the Greek letter Î¾ and is expressed in moles.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #105].

Term.name: Gibbs free energy of reaction

def.defstr: The Gibbs free energy change observed in a thermodynamic system when a substance undergoes a reaction under non standard conditions. The unit of measure is kJ/mol. Symbol: ΔG.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #106]

Term.name: reaction affinity

def.defstr: The negative partial derivative of Gibbs free energy G with respect to extent of reaction at constant pressure and temperature. Affinity is positive for spontaneous reactions in the forward direction. Symbol: ξ.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #106]

Term.name: transformed Gibbs free energy change

def.defstr: A Gibbs free energy that is calculated from the standard Gibbs value (at 298K), and extrapolated to a desired pH and ionic strength, and may be determined at a different temperature. Symbol: ΔG´.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #106]

Term.name: transformed standard Gibbs free energy of reaction

def.defstr: A Gibbs free energy of reaction that is calculated from the standard Gibbs value (at 298K), and extrapolated to a desired pH and ionic strength, and may be determined at a different temperature. Symbol ΔG´.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #106]

Term.name: transformed standard Gibbs free energy of formation

def.defstr: A Gibbs free energy of formation that is calculated from the standard Gibbs value (at 298K), and extrapolated to a desired pH and ionic strength, and may be determined at a different temperature. Symbol ΔGf´.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #106]

Term.name: transformed Gibbs free energy of reaction

def.defstr: The Gibbs free energy change observed in a thermodynamic system when a substance undergoes a reaction under non standard conditions, which is extrapolated to a desired pH and ionic strength, and may be determined at a different temperature. Symbol: ΔG´.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #106]

Term.name: ionic strength

def.defstr: A combined (weighted) measure of the concentration of all electrolytes present in a solution. It is calculated as a half of the sum over all the ions in the solution multiplied by the square of individual ionic valencies. Monovalent electrolytes have a concentration equal to their ionic strength while multivalent electrolytes have greater ionic strength, directly proportional to ionic valency. Symbol: I

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #107]

Term.name: flux balance framework

def.defstr: Modelling approach, typically used for metabolic models, where the flow of metabolites (flux) through a network can be calculated. This approach will generally produce a set of solutions (solution space), which may be reduced using objective functions and constraints on individual fluxes.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #108]

Term.name: flux bound

def.defstr: A parameter that limits the upper or lower value that a flux may assume. This parameter may be determined experimentally, or may be the result of theoretical investigation.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #109].

Term.name: default flux bound

def.defstr: A value used for flux bound in cases where a precise value, supported experimentally or theoretically, is not available.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #109].

Term.name: exchange reaction

def.defstr: A modeling process to provide matter influx or efflux to a model, for example to replenish a metabolic network with raw materials (eg carbon / energy sources). Such reactions are conceptual, created solely for modeling purposes, and do not have a physical correspondence. Exchange reactions, often represented as 'R_EX_', can operate in the negative (uptake) direction or positive (secretion) direction. By convention, a negative flux through an exchange reaction represents uptake of the corresponding metabolite, and a positive flux represent discharge.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #110]

Term.name: demand reaction

def.defstr: A modeling process analogous to exchange reaction, but which operates upon "internal" metabolites. Metabolites that are consumed by these reactions are assumed to be used in intra-cellular processes that are not part of the model. Demand reactions, often represented 'R_DM_', can also deliver metabolites (from intra-cellular processes that are not considered in the model).

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #110].

Term.name: biomass production

def.defstr: Biomass production, often represented 'R_BIOMASS_', is usually the optimization target reaction of constraint-based models, and can consume multiple reactants to produce multiple products. It is also assumed that parts of the reactants are also consumed in unrepresented processes and hence products do not have to reflect all the atom composition of the reactants. Formulation of a biomass production process entails definition of the macromolecular content (eg. cellular protein fraction), metabolic constitution of each fraction (eg. amino acids), and subsequently the atomic composition (eg. nitrogen atoms). More complex biomass functions can additionally incorporate details of essential vitamins and cofactors required for growth.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #110].

Term.name: ATP maintenance

def.defstr: A modeling representation of the energetics of an organism that are attributed to energy costs not directly related to those for growth.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #110].

Term.name: pseudoreaction

def.defstr: A conceptual process used for modeling purposes, often created solely to complete model structure, with respect to providing inflow or outflow of matter or material. Unlike other reactions, pseudoreactions are not usually subjected to mass balance considerations.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #111]

Term.name: sink reaction

def.defstr: A modeling process to provide matter influx or efflux to a model, for example to replenish a metabolic network with raw materials (eg carbon / energy sources). Such reactions are conceptual, created solely for modeling purposes, and do not have a physical correspondence. Unlike the analogous demand (SBO:....) reactions, which are usually designated as irreversible, sink reactions always represent a reversible uptake/secretion processes, and act as a metabolite source with no cost to the cell. Sink reactions, also referred to as R_SINK_, are generally used for compounds that are metabolized by the cell but are produced by non-metabolic, un-modeled cellular processes.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #111]

Term.name: subsystem

def.defstr: Term used to indicate the grouping of model components, largely reactions, by some criterion, often processual. This can be used to indicate, for example, the subsystem of a model that is concerned with 'transport'. A designated subsystem includes reactions annotated with the term, as well as reactions participants such as enzymes, modifiers and genes encoding these subsystem components.

Term.comment: created in response to SF req #113

Term.name: DNA segment

def.defstr: Fragment or region of a DNA macromolecule.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #115]

Term.name: RNA segment

def.defstr: Fragment or region of an RNA macromolecule.

Term.comment: created in response to [SF req #115]

Term.name: allosteric activator

def.defstr: Describes an activator (ligand) which binds at a site other than the active site, resulting in a conformational change, enhancing the activity of the enzyme.

Term.comment: created to facilitate format interconversion (SBML<->BioPAX), see also [SF req #115]

Term.name: non-allosteric activator

def.defstr: Describes an activator (ligand) which binds to the enzyme, which does not result in a conformational change, but which enhances the enzyme's activity.

Term.comment: created to facilitate format interconversion (SBML<->BioPAX), see also [SF req #115]

Term.name: irreversible inhibitor

def.defstr: An inhibitor which binds irreversibly with the enzyme such that it cannot be removed, and abolishes enzymatic function.

Term.comment: created to facilitate format interconversion (SBML<->BioPAX), see also [SF req #115]

Term.name: allosteric inhibitor

def.defstr: An inhibitor whose binding to an enzyme results in a conformational change, resulting in a loss of enzymatic activity. This activity can be restored upon removal of the inhibitor.

Term.comment: created to facilitate format interconversion (SBML<->BioPAX), see also [SF req #115]

Term.name: uncompetitive inhibitor

def.defstr: An inhibitor which binds only to the complex formed between the enzyme and substrate (E-S complex).

Term.comment: created to facilitate format interconversion (SBML<->BioPAX), see also [SF req #115]

Term.name: pMg

def.defstr: An enumeration of the concentration of magnesium (Mg) in solution (pMg = -log10[Mg2+]).

Term.comment: created to facilitate format interconversion (SBML<->BioPAX) and in response to [SF req #117], see also [SF req #117]

Term.name: inhibited

def.defstr: Conceptual or material entity that is the object of an inhibition process, and is acted upon by an inhibitor.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #116]

Term.name: stimulated

def.defstr: Conceptual or material entity that is the object of a stimulation process, and is acted upon by a stimulator.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #116]

Term.name: modified

def.defstr: Conceptual or material entity that is the object of a modification process, and is acted upon by a modifier.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #116]

Term.name: template

def.defstr: An entity that acts as the starting material for genetic production (http://identifiers.org/biomodels.sbo/SBO:0000589).

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #116]

Term.name: mass action rate law for reversible reactions, continuous schema

def.defstr: Reaction scheme where the products are created from the reactants and the change of a product quantity is proportional to the product of reactant activities. The reaction scheme includes a reverse process that creates the reactants from the products. It is to be used in a reaction modelled using a continuous framework.

Term.comment: This term was added on to the tree in response to the term request [SF req #118]

Term.name: molecular mass

def.defstr: A measure of the mass of a molecule derived as a sum of weights of its constituent elements multiplied by the number of atoms of each of the element described by its molecular formula. It is commonly represented using units of daltons.

Term.comment: This term was created by Varun Kothamachu in response to [SF req #119]

Term.name: protein molecular mass

def.defstr: A measure of the total mass of a protein described as a sum total of the weight of all its atoms. It is commonly represented using units of daltons.

Term.comment: This term was created by Varun Kothamachu in response to [SF req #119]

Term.name: biomass

def.defstr: A composite representation of material entities required for organismal growth. It includes macromolecular content (eg. cellular protein fraction), metabolic constitution of each fraction (eg. amino acids), and atomic composition (eg. nitrogen atoms).

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req #120]

Term.name: reversible process

def.defstr: A sequential series of actions, motions, or occurrences, such as chemical reactions, where a reversal of states that bring the system back to its original state in a characteristic manner occurs.

Term.comment: Created by Varun Kothamachu In response to [SF req #96]

Term.name: irreversible process

def.defstr: A sequential series of actions, motions, or occurrences, such as chemical reactions, where a reversal of states that bring the system back to its original state in a characteristic manner does not occur.

Term.comment: Created by Varun Kothamachu in response to [SF request #96]

Term.name: polymerization

def.defstr: A chemical reaction in which one or more monomer molecules combine to form a larger polymer molecule with repeated structural units.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: depolymerization

def.defstr: A chemical reaction in which a large polymer breaks into its constituent monomers (or mixture of monomers).

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: co-transport reaction

def.defstr: A biochemical process involving the simultaneous transport of two or more substances across a membrane via a protein or protein complex.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: transport reaction

def.defstr: The movement of an entity/entities across a biological membrane mediated by a transporter protein.

Term.comment: Created in response to [SF req#121]

Term.name: activation

def.defstr: A conformational change in a protein resulting in its activation.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: active transport

def.defstr: Protein assisted movement of molecules across a membrane from a region of low concentration to high concentration involving the consumption of cellular energy (ATP molecules).

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: passive transport

def.defstr: Movement of molecules without the need for external energy, and usually from a region of high concentration to low concentration.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: symporter-mediated transport

def.defstr: A membrane protein mediated transport of two ore more molecules in the same relative direction across a membrane.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: antiporter-mediated transport

def.defstr: A membrane protein mediated transport of two or more molecules in opposite directions across a membrane.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #121]

Term.name: capacity

def.defstr: Total amount that can be contained or produced by a specific entity. This can refer to diverse items, such as the carrying capacity of a membrane with respect to proteins, the capacity of high-energy phosphate bonds, or the maximal count of bacteria in the gut, etc.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #123]

Term.name: occupancy

def.defstr: Occopancy is a quantitative systemic property that indicates which number of available places is occupied. This can refer to diverse things, such as the number of occupied high-energy phosphate bonds in ATP, the number of bacteria in the gut, or the number of electrons loaded onto redox carriers, etc.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #124]

Term.name: fractional occupancy

def.defstr: Fractional occupancy is a quantitative dynamic property of a system that can be calculated as the fraction of occupancy over capacity.

Term.comment: Term created in response to [SF req #125]

def.defstr: an entity which physical constituents are partially or totally contained in a defined compartment.
